Love Love Love the late night hours.  On Columbus, at Beach Blanket Babylon Boulevard (right across the street from Naia).  Cash only.

Plus: if you sit outside, there's guaranteed quality people-watching opportunities.  You can also entertain your voyeuristic self and look up into the apt. buildings across the street and watch: 1) creepy bald guy working on his computer; 2) young curly-haired guy dancing his butt off (or was he playing soccer by himself!?) and 3) anonymous pair of black-booted & black-jeaned, crossed legs jutting out of a window.

Apparently, authentic, Italian-speaking Italians work and congregate here.

photos posted.
author: Olma M.

description: Ripoff alert. Spend your cash only elsewhere...at least somewhere that appreciates your patronage.
author: Eileen M.

description:
There's something so comforting to me about this kind of old-school Italian bakery and gelateria!!  The smells, the sight of all those drool-inducing desserts in the bakery case, it's enough to render this girl incapable of making up her mind!!

This is the best place to end your date on North Beach:  whether you consume one of their tasty cannoli (mmm, chocolate chips!), their to-die-for gelato, or a gigantic slice of their rich chocolate cake, it's bound to make your mouth water and taste buds croon!!  There aren't a lot of tables, which is perfect:  it means that it won't be super noisy while you and your date sip your delicious latte's and chat while making goo-goo eyes at each other.  I recommend sharing the gelato - it's a lot more filling than it looks!  I've had gelato all over this country and in Italy, and I have to say that this is some of the best, most flavorful-without-being-cloying gelato I've ever had...and it's consistently good!  

If you're looking for a trendy night spot, this is not the place...but the beauty of Mara's lies in what it is:  a bakery selling good Italian pastries, gelato, and coffee.  It does what it's supposed to do and does it well...what's not to like?!!!
author: Amy L.

description: Dessert for breakfast? Sign me up. I think my boyfriend and I were the first customers of the day. We got a cannoli and a slice of tiramisu. I think they only take cash. I thought both desserts were pretty good and it tasted authentic. And by that I mean that we sat outside at a tiny wrought iron table for two and ate our desserts and pretended we were at a bistro in Europe. You can too!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Mara's, for me, is just that dependable pastry place. The chocolate dipped cannoli (my favorite) is always flaky-crusted on the outside, perfectly creamy on the inside, and make me molto felice on MY inside. 

One complaint, though, is that sometimes the pastries that are supposed to be warm are... not. I wouldn't say they're stale or old, just... cold.  

Also, a warning: my review might be a little biased because I think I'm in love with the Italian guy who works here. Keeps me comin' back for more!
author: Kylie M.

description: Pastries were not fresh, coffee bland an soapy.
author: Natasha S.

description: Admittedly I only come here once a year for Christmas cookies. They've got a great selection. Almond macaroons are perfect. Some iced sugar cookies that go great with Christmas morning coffee. Jellys, sandwich varieties. Primo. Cash only. Always smiling and willing to throw together a great assortment in the fly.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
I have to come here to get my biscotti fix everytime I'm in the city. The best is the anise.  It just goes so perfectly with a nice cup of Joe.  The amaretto cookies are perfectly soft and chewy.
Word to the wise, I have seen some of the cakes come out of Costco boxes like red velvet before.  Not sure if that is still done or if it was a one time thing. They do make all their cookies and pastries though.
Lavazza coffee is brewed  there as well as wonderful hot chocolate and gelato.
Bring enough cash which is all they take.  I usually end up spending $20 on a dozen amaretto cookies and 6-8 pieces of biscotti. They go by the weight.
author: Casey T.

description:
Like many others before me I was drawn to this place by the looks of all the tasty pastries at the windows.  I ordered an almond croissant and a cappuccino to go.  All for a hefty price of a little over 7 bucks.  

The croissant was crumbly and stiff.  I also realized that I don't really like almonds in pastries.  So that was a fail.

The cappuccino was scalding--too hot to drink on my walk to work.  Though perfect if you want to bring it in for a buddy you'll see in 15 minutes.  

The old Italian man behind the counter was so friendly and funny that, just because of him, I am going to make an effort to come back again and try another pastry.  Good customer service will do that.
author: Linda T.

description: Walking into Mara's feels like the clock got turned back 30 years. The owner was very friendly and I got two pignolia cookies with a cup of Joe. Just the way I like them! Price is low too.
author: Athena C.

description: What can I say....Its been 4 months and I still remember some of their pastries vividly. Everything I tasted was great but the chocolate covered bearclaw (I am a sucker for bearclaws) and the chocolate chip rolled pastry were stand outs. Add some great coffee (if it is a strong Americano then its good coffee in my book) and you have a perfect match. I stumbled on this shop while walking from Chinatown towards Fisherman's Wharf. I would get it again in a minute, sitting outside and enjoying the day...what a great experience we had.
author: Kevin C.

description:
All I can say about this wonderful pastry and coffee shop... yummy! There are so many traditional Italian pastries starting at around $3.50 a piece. It was hard for me to choose just one! So I went for the variety box and selected one large palm, two almond croissants, 1 apricot and 1 raspberry twist. Of course you can not forget the cappuccino! My friend and I enjoyed for breakfast the next morning and for the evenings dessert. The pastries are so large we had to split, so looks like we have another day to enjoy! I am definitely coming back next time I visit my friend in North Beach! 

Bonus: They stay open until midnight on Sat night!
Remember to bring cash! Cash only!
author: Christine D.

description: Worst service ever. Came in for a thanksgiving desert with family a half hour before closing got kicked of the tables where we were having our coffee. Then 15 min till the locked the doors and refused all customers. While the holiday hours were posted on the door and clearly stated that they were suppose to be open.
author: Nicole C.

description:
Part II: 2007 San Francisco Getaway

My husband and I ended up at Mara's for breakfast. It is a very small bakery. I felt like I was in the movie from the God Father! Talk about going back in time!  This place is a true Italian bakery.  The owner was very friendly. I love pastries and  felt overwhelmed. There were so many choices. OMG... pastries GALORE! I wanted to go all out and buy and taste everything but I settled for the Chocolate Croissant and a Cup of Joe. The Croissant is okay. I had better. But the real reason we came to this bakery was for one thing only!  CANNOLI.... I felt very guilty having a Cannoli early in the morning after I just finished a Chocolate Croissant but it was worth the guilt because  Mara's Cannoli's was DELISH! Just right. Everything about it was nice. Not too crunchy or soggy and not too sweet either. It really had a nice balance. We enjoyed it so much, that we went back to the bakery for a box of Cannoli's before we headed to the airport to bring back home!
author: Anna J.

description: We came here with my sister, boyfriend and nephew. The taste of he coffee was decent, cookies were ok, and the prices were ok too. If you go here please come with cash. They only take cash. I thought that this was an inconvinience given that it is located in such a busy street (columbus ave). Compared with the other bakery around the corner, the other was better.
author: Ibelig V.

description: It has nothing to do with "Italian". You get Sweet like hell Cake or tasteless tiramisu, and on top cash only... I won't be back
author: Rafal N.

description:
Once I saw the Cannoli's behind the glass, like Pavolov's dog's my mouth began to water. 

I purchased 2 Cannolis and a slice of their veggie focaccia pizza.  The total came out to a little over $11.00 .... Absolutely worth the price, as the food was spectacular.

North Beach is a hip spot on the weekends -- typically this tiny shop will have a line out the door. 

I am happy I don't live to close and visit only occasionally, otherwise I would be one fat bastard. This shop has too many tasty looking morsels to try out.
author: Cord N.

description:
Happened to walk past Mara's on a Sunday evening a little bit before 10:30 pm, and was lured inside by the dozens of pastries that were just whispering sweet nothings into my ear from behind the glass. The second thing I notice is the cash only sign. I think to myself: "thank god I went to the ATM earlier." (I don't usually carry cash.) And then it was hell.

By hell, I mean from having to make a decision because THERE ARE SO MANY PASTRIES TO CHOOSE FROM AND THEY ALL LOOK SO DAMN GOOD. I spent a minute just staring at the choices and my mind overloaded. So I did what any sensible gentleman would do... I told my girlfriend that I'd share something with her and that she could choose. :)

Anyway. We ended up getting a chocolate dipped cannoli ($4.75) which was absolutely delicious. It was a good treat after our dinner, and just made the evening a little better. We were lucky enough to walk in just four minutes before they close (at 10:30 pm on Sundays, apparently). After reading some more of the reviews, I'm sure I'll be back to try some of the apple turnovers. 

Definitely have many more shops and restaurants in this area to explore and adventure in. 

Oh and we took public transportation & walked, so we didn't worry about parking, although I could definitely see that as being a huge problem during the day. (It is SF, after all.) But this isn't that much of a walk from Chinatown or the Powell BART station. I love being on foot in SF.
author: Mitty C.

description:
I've walked by here a few times since moving to SF.  The window lures you in...pastries of all sorts sitting there.  EVERY tourist that walks by slows down--and I was guilty of it too.

I ordered: 1 chocolate croissant.
Seemed  2 day old and not your typical chocolate croissant with a chocolate-bar like substance inside.  It had a weird chocolate brownie consistency inside of it that tasted totally off. $3.75 for that.

1 focaccia with just cheese. 
I will say that it tasted very FRESH but nothing special at all.  Also 3.75.

Overall, the window gets ya every time!  Disappointed.
author: Angelica M.

description: Nice spot for espresso, gelato, and some kick butt pastries and desserts
author: Michael B.

description: Apricot pastry was adequately flaky, fairly large and had a price to match. Cannoli was expensive for what you got though!
author: Deborah C.

description: This is another of those places that my family used to drag us to during our San Francisco expeditions, and after some confused driving around Washington Square (which is the only way I remembered where it was), the boy and I had to make the tough choice -- what to get?  We ended up with a bearclaw (delicious!), a little fruit tart, and a chocolate-dipped apple fritter (really dense and filling).  It was good, but I felt it was a little pricy.  There also isn't much space to sit, so get your pastries to go!
author: Sara C.

description: Yummy Yummy just went to this Mara's Italian Pastries and bought myself some Chocolate Cream Puffs which goes really great when you have a cup of coffee or tea with it... I will be back on another time to try something different the next time, when I go back to Mara's Italian Pastries...
author: William B.

description:
As much as I want to give them at least three stars my conscience won't allow me to. On a saturday night in north beach we got a parking space right across the street. I had really high hopes for Mara's. We walk up and are greeted by this beautifully delicious looking display of pastries. I'm thinking oh my we are in Italian pastry heaven. "Cash only," ok, i've got some of that. I should have asked for a sample because we went on a "give me one of those and one of those and one of those" ordering spree. Like I said earlier they look beautifully delicious but they taste plain and disappointing. 
Schubert's on Clement has a beautiful display of cakes and other goodies and they taste as good as they look.
author: Brett W.

description: I was in the area an craving some pastries to have with coffee. This place has a good assortment of Italian pastries. I recommend the shortbread cookies that have a chocolate center. And the cookies with almond and chocolate. Very good.
author: Natalie G.

description:
The window - I love that window...especially at night when you are looking for something sweet or savory and are not sure you know exactly what it is that will satisfy you and seeing them in all their glory as your eyes get bigger and bigger. If you can get pass that - they also have gelato.

Why do the cannolis taste so much better at Mara's??? I know they are from Dianda's - it must be the added ambiance and the North Beach feel. If you are in the hunt for cannoli or good amaretti in the middle of the evening without having to sit down - this is the place.
author: Dee Z.

description: The pastries are phenomenal, I cant wait to go back. My favorite? The Napoleon, crazy awesome! Seriously, I cant wait to go back. I passed on buying a raspberry twist dipped in chocolate, I really want to go back and try that.
author: Trevor N.

description:
This place has a million options to choose from.  I've been here a few times, but I always get the same thing...their connolis! Today I got a chocolate chip cannoli.  The shell was half dipped in chocolate.  It was very yummy!

I'm giving it 4 stars b/c the shop is very small.  It can get busy with no place to sit. Also, no bathroom ;(
author: Anna S.

description:
Let me preface this by saying that the 1 star is not for the pastries, rather, for the major attitude from the pri#k behind the counter.  We were the only ones at the counter, and he was too busy chatting on his cell phone to help us. When he did decide to hang up and see what we wanted, he hardly answered our questions and made no eye contact whatsoever.  Rude and arrogant.  

As for the pastries, the cannoli we had wasn't bad; 3.5 stars.
author: Michael R.

description:
¡Mamma Mia!
this is the best Italian bakery in SF. In fact I have seen many coffee shops around that actually get their bake goodies from here. I love the fact that they are open until the wee hours and every single time I go out in North Beach I make a stop here and end the night with the perfect pastry. Worth the drive from anywhere in the city! My favorite: tiramisu, apricot danish and their rasperry roll half dipped in dark chocolate. To die for!
author: Sandra C.

description:
Great pastries, coffee, and tea.. horrible service. 
 
I have been coming to this place periodically over the last decade, and they have been quite consistent at both product quality and bad service. 
 
But I keep coming back, so I can't give them too low a rating, their product is good, and location is great. ANYTHING ELSE? NEXT!
author: Alex F.

description: Cannolis looked really good, but I wasn't a fan of the flavor or the texture. The cream wasn't the melty cannoli cream that I've grown accustomed to tasty and the shell just didn't seem right either. It wasn't a flakey like texture, more of an ice cream cone type, which just seem right for a cannoli...at least not the good cannoli's that I've had. The eclairs looked good and I think I recall mi compadre (or amico...that's italian right?) saying it was alright.
author: Lily K.

description: Who are the crazies giving this heavenly pastry mecca fewer than 5 stars and why are they allowed to be a part of polite society?! The only reason I would rate this place lower than that is that I can never decide what lovely treats to buy between all the delectable options. I happened across this place one day and not knowing the neighborhood, was heartbroken to not be able to find it again. People walking by the windows oooh and ahhh, without even tasting the stuff. That's fine, low-ratings people. More for us! PS: Locale is nearby  the corner of Stockton and Columbus, across the street from the bank. :)
author: Kate J.

description: Every time I am in North Beach , i have to stop by.  They have the best home made Pastries! I always get the Chocolate swirl sticks and eclairs! All the pastries are to die for.  Please try this mom and pop shop you will not be disappointed.
author: Susie S.

description:
I passed by the window display and couldn't resist! They had pastries to foccacia, everything to ruin your diet but make your day. I got a huge slice of chocolate cake that was moist and all too delicious. It was hard to decide what NOT to get. 

The men behind the counter weren't all too welcoming but at least they weren't sourpusses. There was a couple small tables inside but I'd recommend taking your goodies on the go. 

Although the prices are a bit more than others, I must admit. I guess if you're walking by then by all means stop in. If not, this isn't one of those MUST go to places. Mara's is what it is: a small pastry shop in North Beach. It's not a bucket list place for sure.
author: Elaine T.

description: You're visiting San Francisco? Want something that I guarantee you've never had as good anywhere else, unless you're old school from NYC or Chicago. The tirramisu was way awsome. So soft and light. Espresso, Hot Chocolate whatever is excellent. Cookies are wonderful too. Only takes cash. So how long do you think this place has been around? I can assure you, it's over 20 years. So don't go to some "new" place. Go where the locals and regulars go, to the place that's been in the same hole in the wall, all 5 tables, cash only location forever. You won't be disappointed.
author: Eric K.

description: Cute little place in north beach. decent dessert menu with good coffee to pair with. I dislike the fact that they don't take Credit Card, otherwise I could have spend much more money and stock up on desserts. Cash only policy limit my buying power as I am plastic advocate. Also I was there on a Saturday afternoon and I witnessed the owner and what apparently looks like his son was yelling and insulting their Spanish employee because she was 10 minutes late  to work and calling her stupid in Spanish. Guys, you live in Cali and a lot of people understand Spanish even-though they don't look like it. I thought that was unprofessional and insulting not only for the employee but for the customers as well.
author: Shadi K.

description:
I was shocked to see some of the high-star reviews on here.  Maybe the Saturday night we went was different somehow.  Someone else may have been responsible for the shop while the usual owner was on vacation, or there was some horrible tragedy that took all their time and made them fill their shop with frozen goods that evening.  Whatever the cause, the descriptions in some of the 4 or 5 star reviews here do not seem like the same place we visited - so different that I actually looked at all the pictures on the off-chance I was on the wrong listing.  I wasn't.

The woman at the front counter was unfriendly and seemed annoyed she was there.  The eclair we ordered had clearly been frozen and defrosted, so it was dry with bland custard that had an odd texture.  I'm pretty sure one of their cookie options was just Lofthouse pink frosted sugar cookies from the grocery store - I used to get those all the time, so I recognize them.

If I'm in the area again, I might give it a shot at a different time of day to see if my visit was an anomaly, but as it stands right now, I'm unimpressed.
author: Nate S.

description: Old, dry pastries. Not worth the stop. Keep walking.
author: L T.

description:
My GF and I made this our must-stop bakery in SF....

Reason for 3 stars and not 5:

---very unfriendly staff
---expensive
---hard to find parking on Colombus

Other than these minor issues....it's fantastic.

After a long day of shopping or site seeing, you may need a sugar rush or a jolt of joe...stop in here. It's a party in your mouth whether you try the crisp biscotti or creamy and flaky Napolean.---my favorite.

I heard a rumor that they get their baked goods from a bakery down the street... I have yet to get the clue as to which one.. But I am determined to find out so I can cut out the middle man with major TUDE!... Cmon dude, smile, get your employees to smile and ask how your day is going...it's the least you can do as we pay at least $10 bucks for a latte and a piece of cake. 

---Traditional Italian Baked Goods
---Espresso Bar
---Gelato

If you ask for it go...be sure to get a pink box with string... its so old school. Gotta love feelin like a straight up Italian in NY after visiting Mara's Cafe.

Gotta give a shout out to my homie Anne Marie for introducing me to this place...

Funny story for those of you who are still reading......

My gal pal and I were on our way back from an excursion in the city and yes of course Mara's was our cherry on top. 

We got lost, made an illegal U-TURN getting on the Golden Gate....Got pulled over and pretended to be lost with our map out.
Two extremely hot and sexy CHPs pulled us over....

Gave em our story as they peaked around the car...asked what we did. We summed up our day....they ask what's in the boxes? 
So we couldnt help but bribe them with our cream filled cannolis....said just as so....they couldnt help but LOL.

Definitely a memorable SF trip....Give it a shot, it may even get you out of a ticket. =)
author: Maronita I.

description:
This is a wonderful little bakery that I have been going to for decades. It is the "real" North Beach of days gone by..a neighborhood joint for locals and the occasional tourist who recognizes "authentic" when they see it. 

I've had every pastry here, and my favorite is the cannolli, mmmmmmm. I always pick up a big box for holiday dinners, and people inhale them!

Call a week ahead for a large order. It used to be a few days but they seem to be much busier these days!

They also have lots of great coffee drinks and focaccia.

Everything is good here, enjoy!
author: Sharon J.

description: We had some good treats here in the past, but then had some really bad ones. In particular, a semi frozen tiramisu and stale cookie.
author: Captain B.

description: The best Rapsberry Rings are from Mara's, hands down. This North Beach institution has the best Italian pastries. If you can't go to Italy, don't worry - you have Mara's. Don't forget your cash because they don't take cards. Absolutely and totally worth the effort to get over there.
author: Hotel B.

description: I've been buying pastries from Mara's for over 25 years.  They have the best raspberry rings!
author: Gayle B.

description:
If you are looking for a spot to pop in for some wonderfully fresh and authentic italian pastry, then Mara's is must.  The atmosphere is very basic, so don't plan on table service, but instead take your time indulging in the sight of the lovely baked goods.  Busy foot traffic with most patrons taking their treat and coffee to go, but a handful of tables are available for those who can linger to stay and enjoy their treat.  Mara's is one of the few places in the Bay Area to have my favorite, sfogiatelle, a scallop shaped southern Italian pastry.  It's not as good as the one I had in Italy, but good enough to stir the memory.  I loved thinking that I got THE LAST ONE, only to learn that they had put more in the oven; they bake them off a few at a time so that they are only serving the freshest pastry possible.  I think I fell in love a little bit when I heard that.  

I took off one star due to them only taking cash only.  So bring cash, and enjoy.
author: Michele M.

description: Everything looked sooo good and I really wanted some kind of cake for my birthday.  We ordered a mini pecan pie, some kind of chocolate mousse cake (bar shaped), chocolate cake with strawberries, whipped cream eclair, and amaretto gelato.  None of it was good. so sad.  The gelato was probably the best of the bunch but it wasn't rich dense gelato, it was rather a unspectacular ice cream.  The service wasn't very friendly either, the girl working seemed annoyed at having to explain what everything was but there were no labels or signs and they have quite a variety.  They had a chocolate mousse type round cake and another bar type and she said they were the same when I asked the difference, they were obviously different with different layers but she did not want to describe and simply insisted they were the same. I went with the bar because it looked more interesting with more layers but it was a bad choice. Tasted really stale and old.
author: Sj C.

description: The place is right on Columbus in the heart of North Beaches restaurant row. Its an older bakery, but the baked goods are delicious. One of my husbands favorite stops in NB. We stopped by today to grab a cannoli and a biscotti for our walk. I had a white chocolate covered almond biscotti very tasty. My husband inhaled his treat so it must have been A OK.
author: Susan D.

description:
Their window full of goodies always pulls me in like a moth to the light.  They've got cannolis and decently good focaccia, though for the latter I prefer the freshly baked at Liguria Bakery.  If in a bind and in need of a quick snack, Mara's will do. 

But lately I've been preferring Stella over Mara for their pastries and biscotti, ambiance too.
author: Joanne G.

description: We did a sampling there at about 11pm last night after a good meal.  We tried about five different things.  All were really tasty.  There was some kind of raspberry ring pastry that was out of this world.
author: Ken L.

description: Dianda's Pastries deliver their goods here around 6:45am or earlier you can see a truck out on Green street dropping it off. After that I watch driver at Roma Cafe too! So a lots of these places are ordering from other places, telling customers it's made on site lol.
author: James K.

description:
We had been walking for the better part of the day and needed to caffeine and carb up. 

Between my bf and I we had a double espresso, macchiatto, tiramisu, chocolate almond biscotti, and chocolate-dipped canoli. 

Everything was average. I'm guessing their income is based on good location rather than reputation of deliciousness.
author: Jen K.

description:
My several experiences here have me going back every time I in North Beach.
Love the old time vibe of a window full of pastries!
Older guy very pleasant each time and explains the good to this old Pollack.
My son has inherited my love of good sweets, doesn't mind disagreeing with his old man, and he like this joint as well. Rich, buttery, flavorful pastries, perfect for a morning sugar rush. Not cheap, but what large city is?
Nice bit of San Francisco.

Mark C
author: Mark C.

description:
My experience at Mara's left a bad taste in my mouth - in more ways than one.

I frequent Chinese restaurants a lot, so I'm usually not fazed by poor customer service. But the lack of hospitality here really irked me. Combined with the unimpressive cookies I had here, I felt compelled to write my first one-star review.

Not being very familiar with Italian pastries (well, I *do* know what biscotti are - thanks to Starbucks!), I had a few questions regarding what all the cookies in their display case were. It didn't help that most of them are unlabelled (except for the biscotti - *those* were labelled. Sigh...) When I asked though, the guy behind the counter was so rude. He barely made eye contact with me and seemed really annoyed. The one-word descriptions didn't help me much either.

I ended up getting what he described as an almond cookie and a meringue. They weren't horrible, but I prefer my desserts to be good-enough-to-be-worth-being-fat-for and these were definitely NOWHERE near that. Not only were they sub-par, the "meringue" wasn't really a meringue. It was just a regular crunchy cookie. In fact, it was basically the same thing as the almond cookie without the thick coating of powdered sugar.

Even though they were tiny I only ate about a quarter of each before throwing them away. As much as I hate wasting money (so not worth the $1) and food, they weren't worth the extra 5 minutes at the gym!
author: Steph L.

description: Whenever I come in here, I can never settle on one pastry. Everything looks so delicious, I end up getting multiple treats. The pastries are always fresh and the staff is very patient and helpful. I love this place!
author: Jane P.

description:
I will follow up behind W. H.'s review and sorry if I offend anyone here. Want to know why this place went from good to shit? Lazy ass Mexican women who work there could care less about you, your order, or the bakery they work in so long as they collect a paycheck. Sorry, and yes I am a bit prejudice, but the facts are there. 

I walked in to look over the pastries and also to get a latte. The two women behind the counter never once even looked at me. I was the only one in the place!!! I stood there for about a good 5 mins as they talked it up and FINALLY one of them looked at me. I said hello and she went back to chit chatting. I just finally blurted out my order and got a latte, but she only filled up the cup little more than half way..WTF??
I also ordered an eclair which was pretty old by the taste... I am not exaggerating. I also too noticed the place to be pretty disorganized and signs in the displays did not match up.
As I was on my way out a family of 4 came in to get gelato and the two women working there were too concerned about the Kohl's sale ad and basically ignored them till someone said something to them twice. 

If the owner reads this congrats on saving cash by hiring two POS workers for few bucks an hour. I will never go back and will never recommend it. If it goes under it will make a great taco shop!
author: Carl S.

description: I love this place.  This is always my first stop when I am in North Beach.  Gino is always so awesome and so is the staff.  The pastries are amazing and I feel so at home here.  My son LOVES the gelato.  Personally, it is my favorite gelato in San Francisco.  It reminds me of the gelato I used to have as a child.  I highly recommend this place.  Stop by and you will see what I mean.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I know a manager at Costco - Mara's literally buys many if not most of their pastries from Costco.  It's a scam!

I had chocolate cake there once; it tasted like high fructose corn syrup.  I complained that it tasted like Safeway cake; later I found out that it's actually Costco's chocolate cake.

I live in north beach and walk my dog every night; every time I've walked past Mara's I've seen pastries (elephant ears) out in the open air, on trays sitting on top of the display cases.  Many times, I've seen mice running across the counter inside the window.  That's disgusting.
author: craig v.

description:
This is THE Italian bakery in the heart of North beach. It's the only Italian bakery I ever go to. I love the canoli but my favorite thing is the little puff pastry balls covered in chocolate that have caramelized liquor covering them. YUM! Maybe it's rum? Yum Yum balls of chocolate rum!

I have to have these every time I'm in SF. 

I no longer live in SF but work here and on occasion I'm there on weekends. When I am in SF on weekends this is what my day usually looks like....

Wake up and discuss going to SF
Discuss that whatever it is we are doing HAS to involve a Mara's drive by
Drive into SF and do our thing
Head to Mara's
I jump out of the car with 30$ and Mr.Kelly circles the block
I buy as much as I can with 30$ 
Run outside and jump back into the car
Head for the bridge and try not to eat everything in the bag


CASH ONLY
Small inside
They have Gelato and cafe drinks... but you must try the pastry! (especially the little booze puff pastry chocolate balls. They are heaven
author: Kelly C.

description:
I always refer this bakery... to friends, family, tourists, basically anyone who will listen! :)

The pastries are delicious, it's a quaint little mom-and-pop's type place and it's centrally located.  Pricing isn't too steep, cash only, there's also gelato, espresso, and outdoor seating.

My personal faves are the chocolate covered cream puffs, the chocolate cake, and the Sfogliatelle.   

Every year for Christmas I send home a big box of biscotti and cookies.  They're a huge hit!

Enjoy!
author: Carrie B.

description:
Unless I have a serious craving for a slice of red velvet cake, I can't imagine every venturing into Mara's again to place a medium or large sized order. 

The cannoli, cake, and various cookies we picked up for a dinner party's dessert course were wonderful! Especially the velvet cake. It was moist, perfectly rich while still feeling light, and laced with fresh and creamy frosting. We didn't even bother putting the pastries on plates and instead laid a pile of forks on the table and just picked away at everything until we were left with a mess of crumbs and torn pastry liners inside a battered pink pastry box. There is no need to second guess Mara's for its product, and this fact has made it difficult for me to give it so few stars. However.....

The service was outright terrible. The women working paid little attention to us when we walked in, and never asked if we needed help or were ordering for ourselves or would like a box. As soon as I was able to make contact with the counter woman, she grabbed a small bag and stared in question without saying a word. I told her I'd need a box, and as I was pointing to pastries, she grabbed them without giving me the opportunity to ask as to their contents or specify how many I wanted. When I did get questions out in time, she would look away outside or around the shop while answering- hardly making eye contact or showing any enthusiasm.

If you need a large order of Italian sweets, venture elsewhere- there are plenty of place in North Beach besides Mara's. But if you're craving red velvet cake...and can tolerate the 20 second face time that transaction would require...then Mara's is it.
author: Raquel C.

description: Used to always come here for their pastries, but after yesterdays experience I won't be back.  The pastry I received was definitely old and stale. I had to fight the employees just to receive a new one.
author: Brendan S.

description: Pastries are good.  The woman behind the counter could care less about you or your experience.
author: Victor C.

description:
I still somehow keep my vow of never passing up this place. 

Last night even after a gigantic dinner & just a quick stop at the pharmacy, I found myself making illogical decisions down the street:

-If this light doesn't turn green in 15 seconds, I'm walking 2 blocks up to Mara's. 
-I should take the long way home AND uphill to work off dinner. 
-I don't even like sweets. 
-Oh, gelato up the street is healthier than ice cream. 
-Gelato? Nut case. Cookies by the pound at Mara's is MUCH better. 

Fine, you win Mara. After arguing with myself the whole 2 blocks up. I ended up getting their yummy cookies with fruit jam and a mouth watering chocolate brittle cookie. Even at 9pm, they still had a large selection of treats!

I'm sure the walk home uphill cancels out the cookies I ate. :)
author: Catherine O.

description:
I recently went into Mara's on a Monday night when our usual place was closed. The pastires looked good from the window, but they had foccia pizza just out in the open in the window, not even covered. Once we got in, the pastires were OK...but here's what irked me. I think the manager was off that day because the staff had their personal, dented water bottles in the Gelatto case to keep cold I guess. Then two of the staff members were holding a table so they could eat their dinner right there in the open. Therefore customers had to stand. I will not go back there ever again. This is not very good customer service. At our other pastry place we like to sit and lounge and people watch, but this was horrible. We left shortly after the last canoli crumb was eaten. 

Oh now that I look at Carl S.'s review, he mentioned the lazy a$$ staff. I think its the same people!
author: Sue S.

description:
"Holy Cannoli!"
The North Beach area seems to change every two weeks. More restaurants, less bakeries & delis.
Hate going to a bakery and pay a dollar plus for a little cookie.
At Mara's, we found a good old fashion Italian bakery with gigantic pastries e.g., the apricot turnovers.
Nice assortment of biscotti.
Ma il pezzo forte was the cannoli! The bomb!
Nice Italian coffee drinks.
Cash only.
author: Rosquete B.

description:
I went to pastry school and learned how to make delicious things.  My search for a new career crashed upon the rocky shoals of economic reality and I did something else.  I still remember how to make real pastry and know what it tastes like.  Not the soggy, tooth-curlingly sweet trash from Costco or Safeway.  The real thing.

Mara's makes amazing pastry.  The texture is the perfect blend of flaky and tender.  The filings are just sweet enough.  Plus, they still make a proper bittersweet chocolate twist. Take your out-of-town guests here for breakfast in North Beach and show them what pastry is supposed to taste like.
author: Stephen N.

description:
Read: two and half starts. 

We've stopped here a few times when having dinner in North Beach. Everything is good, but then again, I've never met a pastry I didn't like. Nothing is labeled here so it's impossible to know how much things are or what they are. While everything is tasty, the prices are insane. 

Last night we stopped in after having pizza and pasta at Tony's around the corner. I decided to get some goodies for Sunday's breakfast and also to feed the babysitter (gotta keep those babysitters well fed and happy!). I ordered 2 apple fritters, 1 chocolate/raspberry ring, 2 fruit filled danish, and 6 cherry/chocolate chip biscotti. I almost fell over when the total was $31 and change.

I asked how much each item was but had a hard time understanding the person who was helping me.  Her English wasn't good and my Italian is zero . I think she over charged me but since no prices are displayed and I couldn't understand her, who knows. This is a cash only place and no receipt was given.
author: Mrs. M.

description:
This place is really Italian, don't worry! The dude actually SPEAKS italian. My bf was translating their Italian dirty talk, LOL ! Anyways, on to the review!

Cute little spot, and all the goodies in the window just draw you in. We tried their Chocolate-Chocolate cake (SUPER chocolate!) and of course I'm a gelato girl! I loved both the Tiramisu AND Hazelnut. 

I will definitely come back here to hit on them Canolli's!
author: Maureen M.

description: I am very fond of Mara's.  Nothing super fancy but everything is yummy, maybe a little bit overwhelming with the selection.
author: Robert M.

description:
I can't believe they actually stand by their product.

If this is how Italian pastries are supposed to taste, then Italian pastries are shit.

The guy working there arrogantly told my friend that she didn't know anything about quality pastries.

Wrong move, son.  You just insulted the pastry chef for one of SF's finest restaurants.

Don't waste your breath (or your money) talking with the douche employee or buying the shit pastries at Mara's.

La Boulange is on the SAME block and even on their worst day, EVERY SINGLE ONE of their pastries is better than the crap at Mara's.
author: Justin C.

description:
Haven't tried their pastries here and based on their reviews here, I probably will never.  I'm actually not much a pastry person anyways so I shouldn't have a problem restraining but what I did have was their Ice Cream and it was really good.   $2.95 for the small size....

We had the Strawberry flavor and it was a nice treat to have while resting from our walk at the North Beach Festival.  Not much seating but we were able to find one and sit outdoors, eat our ice cream and rest our legs to get ready for more walking....
author: Mark W.

description:
So I thought I'd go to a small business, something authentic in the North Beach hood, vs. picking up a caloric tidbit while at the La Boulangerie chain down the block and boy what a mistake.  8 dollars (yes, 7 bux plus something for the tip jar for two regular old pastries) down the drain, they were simply terrible and not worth eating.  

Good place to go if you are on a diet I suppose, but awful for fulfilling those naughty sweet tooth urges.
author: GIR ..

description: It's really gross they take your money and then get the next persons order touching all the pastry and touching dirty money it's gross
author: cheri h.

description: Had to check it out because my Daughter's name is Mara... So good! Took some cookies and cannoli's to go for my fam.
author: Cat H.

description: We are here in a group of four and all the four pastries we bought were horrible! They all tasted like margarine. Ick!
author: Fernando G.

description:
It's a trap!

I've walked past this charming little pastry shop a thousand times.  A siren song of sugary goodness emanated from the baker's trays placed in the window.  One unsuspecting day, a friend of mine with a highly developed sweet tooth suggested we stop in for dessert.  I couldn't resist.  My defenses were gone.

I'll be the first to admit that perhaps ordering a French clair at an Italian Pastry Shop perhaps wasn't the best choice.  Still.  I expected a pastry, not a caulk filled plywood tube coated in chocolate.  My dining companion's cookie was better but still nothing to write home about.

The saving grace of the establishment was the coffee.  Some days I'm nostalgic for Australia and I'll order a Long Black.  Normally I have to explain the (rather simple) process to the bewildered barista.  This time she looked at me and said, "That's how we make our Americano."  I swooned just a little bit and it dulled the pain of the eclair debacle.

It's an okay spot for a cup of coffee, but you can easily do better in the neighborhood.  Leave Mara's for the tourists.
author: Christopher K.

description: Hubby thought it was the best bear claw he's ever had. I enjoyed the cannolis. Took biscotti and other pastry home. The biscotti was great. The chocolate rolled pastry way to crunchy and boring.
author: Emmy M.

description: What better way to celebrate the season premiere of the Sopranos than with some homemade pizza, wine and good friends? Add some Italian pastries to the mix and we were all set.  I picked up some cannoli at Mara's and was a bit disappointed.  The shells weren't very crispy, actually, they just didn't taste that fresh in general. Next time I'm in the mood for a cannoli I'll head across the street to Stella's instead.
author: phil h.

description:
If you're walking down Columbus on a very cold and rainy night and want to warm yourself up from the inside out, but you've been drinking too much lately and it's a week night and you've promised each other you're going to stop drinking so much even though you definitely don't have a *problem* so a nice cup of coffee makes a lot more sense than a nice bottle of wine, stop in to Mara's in North Beach.   

But, if you're looking for delicious Italian pastries, stop in to Dianda's in the Mission.
author: P J.

description: Pretty standard, lots of biscotti but not much originality in anything else they carry.
author: Alex A.

description: I love, love, love this place. I always make a point to stop her for a cappucino and a pastry when in NB. The prices are cheap, good service, quaint little shop that you can hang out and drink your coffee in. My husband loves the cannolis here too.
author: Kimberly R.

description: Their cannolis seem to be a popular subject so I'll throw in my three cents worth.  I tried one of these a few weeks ago.  It looked pretty good too.  The problem was the shell was chewy and the cream had a slight film on it.  Yes, I considered the price paid as a donation to Mara's, and yes, I spit it out and tossed it.  There are many good Italian bakeries in San Francisco and I learned that Mara's is not one of them.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Holy Cannoli!! I heart this place!! My friend and I had some time to kill before Beach Blanket Babylon when we happened on this small, cute Italian-style bakery and cafe. I've been to Italy several times and it reminded me of those corner little, mom and pop bakeries you see all over Venice or Milan. 

However, just when I was about to hit the "Write a review " button, I couldn't help but spy on some of the previous, less-than-steller reviews. Surprisingly, I found out a few things: 1) Wow, there are a whole lot of super-duper-uper-picky SF divas (can a guy diva be called a devo?), 2) others encountered some "personality issues" with some of the workers and 3) don't the order the Tiramisu. 

It's a good thing I didn't read Yelp because that would have spoiled an absolutely perfect, yet casual pre-show snack. The girl in front of us was probably a regular and the gentleman at the counter greeted her with a smile and comp'ed her cannoli. Suddenly, I almost wished I were a local. 

The cannolis were out of this world, the best one outside of little Italy in NYC. We also enjoyed the lace cookies with the dark chocolate and my espresso was just fine. If I am ever in the area again, I definitely would drop by in a heartbeat! 

This isn't the Ritz nor a full-fledge restaurant, it's a small, small, small place of business. If I had to put up daily with such pretentious, unforgiving, high-strung folks, hey, I'd be a bit grumpy too. So Pop has a bad day, boo-hoo.  Don't let the negative reviews stop you, judge it for yourself. 

So to the folks at Mara: Lei ha una bella panetteria e ho piaciuto le sue pasticcerie molto! Non badare a questi sciocchi!
author: Jenny D.

description:
Get the chocolate cake with chocolate icing and share it with you significant other.

If you're single, eat the whole damn thing by yourself with a big glass of milk or your favorite zin.

Lick the fork, the plate and the wax paper they wrap it in.

They make it fresh on site just about every day.

You have been warned, enter at your own risk.
author: Rob K.

description:
On an early Sunday morning nothing sounds better to me than a Cappuccino and a semi-sweet pastry. I wandered by the display in the window at Mara's and just had to go in. 

I ordered a pastry with a cheese filling which was good. Maybe just personal preference, but I wish they would of heated it up. 

The coffee however was very good. It was hot and strong, a great combination.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Okay. Let's play a game.

Global Thermonuclear... oops... wrong game.

Let's play... Try to make the grumpy counterpeople smile.

Good Luck!

===============

If you, like me, failed that game... there's always some sweets to make yourself feel better. The Amaretto (sp?) cookies (with pine nuts and without), when fresh, are OUTSTANDING. I thought I died and went to cookie heaven. The gelato was pretty good. (I had the Coffee Dutch Almond)... And they do overfill the cups... which is a VERY GOOD THING.

They also serve stuff like espresso drinks and the like... (I guess "pizza" is the like...)

If you're rolling out of a bar in North Beach it's a good place to check out. (there's just something cute about a paper sign that announces your business... I think they've been there forever... but it makes you feel they could leave us at any time.)
author: John M.

description:
my husband just happened to pass by this place a lot of times, and one day decided that i wanna taste the pastries here.  i have had a lot of pastries in my life, im a pastry lover, and i love italian pastries.

their bread looked terrific thru the glass window, sitting on a metal sheet, exposed to the whole store. i went in and got raspberry crullers, almond croissants, and the thin cookies. i dont mind paying 3.50 for each pastry if it was worth it, but the moment i took a bite, i know something was wrong.  

i agree with the person who gave this review a one star who said they were frozen, left over from last night.

they were horrible.  i did not finish my bite and i wasted 11.00,but id rather be good to my teeth and stomach and do them a favor by staying away from the pastries. they tasted old, the texture felt old, it was a disappointment. 

what a shame since mara's is in the little italy proper...

never again im coming back and i dont care what anyone says that this is good. they probably had the fresh ones, and i did not. you gotta give me a break.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Ok, I have never been here, and I can see it's not the BEST bakery in the entire world, but seriously, the chocolate dipped canoli almost made me cry. I literally wanted to weep after placing that creamy goodness against my lips.

The eclair? Pretty good.

I'm not a big cookie fan, but the florentines were yummy. 

And the pink boxes are BACK!
author: Jessica P.

description: Delicious. Delicious. We had 4 different pastry and honestly, they were all good.  I wish I remember what I had but after a day of drinking (santacon), remembering the names of delicious pastry was the last thing on my mind.  I remember having something with chocolate, raspberry and this flat sugary pastry.  Next time.
author: Oriana C.

description:
"Ok the place looks spooky from the sidewalk."

That's my favorite Yelp soundbite about this place. Thanks wendy h.!

I've been wanting to pen a review of Mara's for a long time, but I could never remember the name of the place. That's the problem with little holes in the wall (hole in the walls?). Mara's was always just "that little place on Columbus with all the pastries in the window."

I'm a sucker for places like this.

My mom was in town last weekend, and we dropped into Mara's after a stroll around North Beach. This time I made sure to remember the name. Hence, this review.

My mom had a cheese danish and a cappuccino. The danish was great and reminded us of the ones made by a popular neighborhood German bakery on the edge of Philadelphia. I had what I always have there: an amaretto cookie and a pignoli cookie. They just taste so good with coffee, and the folks at Mara's can pull a great espresso shot.

I branched out and had an eclair there once - when I was feeling especially decadent and sweet toothed. It was delicious.

They lose one star, not because the service is grumpy (for some reason I have a soft spot for that), but because the stuff is not always fresh. How a place would make so many different pastry choices fresh every day is beyond me, so I can't be too hard on them.

There's no better place to snack and read the paper. Makes ya feel like a full on mafioso.
author: Shawn S.

description:
I had a raspberry stick craving at 9:30 PM and herded my posse over to Mara's - close, open till 10:30, sweet pastries!  I was expecting the usual hum drum pastry, but this time, the raspberry RING was even BETTER than I remembered!  Blame it on being crazy from stuffing myself with homemade fried chicken or the cold weather, but the delectable pastry was EXTRA loaded with raspberry jam, EXTRA flaky, and had EXTRA sugary crunch.  This trip might have turned me into an addict....

PLUS - the nice lady who works at night was there.  Her smile is almost as sweet as the pastry!
author: Jane L.

description: I LOVE this place! I crave Italian cookies and lattes and they do everything here just right. Get the dark chocolate florentine or the pignoli nut cookies. Take 4 friends and have a cookie sampling party. Whatever you do, go!
author: Andrew K.

description: Ok the place looks spooky from the sidewalk (do they ever turn on the lights during the day?!?!).  Anyhoo, I was first introduced to Mara's after a couple of friends and I saw Beach Blanket Babylon.  Their  pignoli nut cookies are really good.  The only downside is that the cookies are kinda expensive!
author: Wendy H.

description:
Don't let the pastries lure you in only to be treated poorly.  The one guy behind the counter is the rudest and most unfriendly person we've come across in any service establishment.  It's like you are begging him for the pastries when you are paying him to keep the store open and the staff paid.  

The pastries are ok and you can likely find something of equal quality or better elsewhere.  We had tried the chocolate covered cream puff cluster - it looks better than it tasted.  The chocolate cake is not bad.  The good items are likely purchased from Dianda and sold here. 

Skip.
author: Gloria H.

description: great little spot..!!  every time Im near by I will definitely stop there and get some for me and the fam.. More than 25 years operating . . family business. . yup!!!
author: Nes A.

description:
I ordered a croissant to go. Instead of putting it in a bag, the guy put a tissue around half of it and placed it on the dirty counter. Disgusting. I didn't buy it. As I was leaving the guy said, "Do you want me to heat it up?" What, to kill the bacteria?

Great location for the tourists, so clearly they don't care.
author: fishfry t.

description: My favorite pastry shop in California!!!! Try the Millefolgie! Or the homemade cannoli!
author: Maria A.

description:
I read some of the negative reviews down here, and I don't agree with the harshest comments I have to say. 

Just consider this, EVERY single time I happen to go to Little Italy or being in North Beach, I always stop by Mara Pastries to enjoy their amazing stuff. 

But be aware, what's really very very good here are the ITALIAN PASTRIES, and the name itself suggests! Hence, do not expect to find an amazing and cheap almond croissant, or great coffee beverages... I do think the place is unique of its gender for the proper Italian pastries, and nothing else. 

I love their Millefoglie: the cream (custard?) they use is really delicious and has always tasted really fresh when I tried it , and the millefoglie basis really is perfect. Also their diplomatico (or Neapolitan) is quite impressive. Finally, I also tried the cannoli, both in the big and small versions, and found both great too.

ok, of course they don't add stuff every 20 mins as another reviewer said they claim they do, but still all the Italian pastries really taste very fresh, and it's really really easy not to taste fresh when you have cream, custard or ricotta-based pastries. Also, maybe this really is due to cultural differences, but if the owner of a place tells me he adds stuff every 20 mins, I just take it as to mean they frequently do stuff, and I guess we both know it's just  a way of saying, I can't really see how this kind of comment can define them as liars and then having me dislike the place and not going any more...

I do agree they charge too much for some items, like beverages and also the Italian products they have, like panettone, colomba pasquale...

Hence, again, do go there but onl for their Italian pastries, and I guess you won't be disappointed!
author: france d.

description:
So, it may not be the "best" or the most congenial, but Mara's is the place I'm always drawn back to.  It's just reliable.  They ALWAYS have chocolate florentines, and they always seem to be open when I'm going by.  

I have an addiction to their chocolate florentines, and on my last visit I went out on a limb and tried the white-chocolate florentines.  DON'T DO IT!!   They don't compare.  They were the sad last remaining cookies in the jar at my house -- it was like being the last kid picked for a school sports team -- but they didn't get thrown away.  

Also dared to be different and tried the raspberry ring pastries.  YUM!   Highly recommended.  Not too sugary-sweet, just sweet raspberries.  My mouth is watering.
author: jill j.

description:
I stopped inside Mara's today after going to Cafe Roma for a cappuccino. I did not intend to purchase cookies with my coffee, but I saw the display window with HUGE palmers, bear claws, fritters, pizza, raspberry wreaths, etc. I just had to stop inside.

When I stepped inside, I was very disappointed. The decor looked like a run-down donut shop: dusty with questionable hygiene. The pastries in the cabinet were small and charged by weight. I didn't feel like purchasing anything after seeing the cabinet, but the owner was watching me and I felt odd walking in and then out without buying anything. I purchased a normal sized palmer, which was $1. That was probably not the best choice for me to buy, but I wanted something inexpensive and not too sweet.

The palmer was flaky but slightly stale. It was overly crunchy and a little too sweet for my liking of those heart-shaped cookies. With a plethora of other pastry shops nearby, I do not think I will be coming back (unless I am really in the mood for a raspberry wreath I can wear as a necklace or a fritter 6 inches in diameter).

Note: I have not tried the cannoli nor the napoleons (which got good reviews), but the sign said they were $5.95. I don't care how amazing your cannoli is, no pastry is worth that price.

I recommend Stella's over this place any day. Nicer atmosphere, better pastries, and friendlier customer service for the same price.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Mara's is THE place to get your Italian Pastry fix in San Francisco. They might have some attitude but hey, the italian pastries wouldn't be as authentic without the italian 'tude!! 

Irregardless, amaaazing cannolis and yummy almond cookies...
author: Tabitha O.

description: got the palmier and it was not very good... for $4.25 and tasted more like it was worth $1.25. the texture was all wrong, it was more like bread instead of having flakey layers like it is supposed to, and it was a little stale, and there was a black spot of dirt on it :/
author: Angela Z.

description: I passed this pastry shop today and saw only one customer in the shop. I kind of relieve that people know better now. I once stepped in and out from this shop within few minutes when I recognized that they carry other shops items.
author: Vicki S.

description: I had a sweet tooth and by chance passed this Italian bakery and was pleasantly surprised! The eclair I had was flaky with just enough custard inside, topped off with a thick layer of chocolate! My sweet tooth was more than satisfied that beautiful evening stroll on Columbus ave.
author: John V.

description:
I would have to agree with many of the earlier posts. The pastries i the window look great. I have walked past this place many times. Eve though I do not live in the city, I visit often. Today I was in the mood for something sweet.
After entering I saw most of the pastries looked like they could be store bought. ( I worked as a chef for many years, and have seen pastries that look just like these come out a box. ) Anyway, I ordered a Napoleon. It was good, but not as fresh as I was hoping. The pastry was not as flakey as it should have been. It still had a good flavor.
As for the service, HMMM? The man behind the counter was on a computer when I walked in. He did great me right away, then another customer came in. She looked like she knew what she wated, so I let her order. Then I ordered and ate in the store. I was a little dissapointed on how the place was kept. The table that I sat next to had dirty cups on it, the table I sat at had some powdered sugar on it. When I sat down, the man behind the counter went back to his computer, and did not even bother with any of the dirty tables in the dinning area. Makes me wonder about the back areas.
author: Steve A.

description: Out of the different places in North Beach to get a cannoli, I will say this place wins hands down, though you can certainly get better at Dianda's in the Mission and I've had better in NYC
author: Ben T.

description: Stopped by before seeing Beach Blanket because I happened to glance in their window. How can you not? It's a wonderful, amazing and glorious window full of sweets that can't be missed. We purchased one cannoli for later that evening...quick service, $3.50 for a huge cannoli (or you can get a few smaller ones for a buck less - think about it, a restaurant will charge between $7-10 for the same) and it tasted great several hours later...the pastry was still crisp too! I will definitely go back when I am in the area.
author: VeryBerry F.

description:
Just in case someone (besides me) is actually reading these reviews - the answer is yes, I did eat dinner in Napa and dessert in North Beach.

What's there to say - amazing selection, amazing quality.  If you are looking to splurge on Italian deserts and cappacino - go here!

Cash only - weird.  

Everything tastes fresh - amazing.  

Three people can gorge on fantastic classic Italian patries and espresso for under twenty bucks - outrageous!

[these aren't getting funny yet]
author: jules h.

description:
Much much better than Stella's.  I'm just not impressed by fancy bakeries.  As you walk by this small bakery, you'll immediately see nothing but mouthwatering baked goods in the window.  Now this is what a bakery should look like. 

Had a Napoleon and it was absolutely wonderful.  The flaky crust was softer, so that it was easy to slice through, and the custard filling was perfect, not too sweet at all.  And we had half leftover that was refrigerated that tasted even better once everything had a little time to solidify.  

I've found my new favorite bakery in SF.
author: Henry L.

description:
Somehow I end up here every time I'm in North Beach, even if I've just stuffed my face full of pasta or drank a bunch of beer (or both).  It just always seems right for rounding out the evening.

Cannoli and espresso are basic and good, and I really like the little butter cookies with chocolate in between them, too.
author: Megan D.

description:
I purchased 5 chocolate dipped cannolies and a cappucino.  My cannolies came in a pink box with smile from the 2 gentlemen working there.  The cannolies and my cappucino was very good!  

Note:  They only take cash.
author: Christine S.

description:
only one thing comes to my mind: tourist trap.

It is at an important intersection and it draws people by the luring display. I agree with the negative comments on other reviews. 

I had a pizza focaccia for $4 and it was heated in a microwave. 
If they reheat things up in a microwave, I don't need to go to this place there are tons of other places (e.g. on green st) that give me better stuff cheaper..

I'll never go here again.
author: saurabh S.

description: Their cannolo is medium-sized, has a nice cream cheese taste with some "tang" and a very smooth texture.  The shell is not soggy but is barely crisp and is very fragile and crumbly.  The ends of the shell were dipped in chocolate which again I have zero interest in.  There were two miniature "mystery chocolate chips" inside and there was no citrus or liqueur taste.  Given the cream cheese taste and "tang", this may be the tastiest cream I've had excluding Cavalli's.
author: David E.

description: Stop #3 on my "Eating my way through SF" weekend tour was Mara's in North Beach. My friend who I'm here visiting and I both studied in Italy and I couldn't believe she had never tried a Canoli so I basically dragged her in here and bought us a chocolate canoli and forced her to eat it even though we had just come from stop #1 and we weren't the least bit hungry.......I liked the Canoli from Mara's. It was HUGE!!!
author: Lori K.

description: Underwhelming and small cannoli - and at $3.95, too expensive. You can probably do better in North Beach.
author: Julia K.

description: Great Pastries!!!!!! Only issue I wish they took credit cards so I could have taken several home with me
author: Christopher S.

description:
Great Italian pastries and gelato!  A friend introduced me to Mara's a few months back, and I've been passing on the good word since (except in my version I found it on a whim, shhhhh).

The gelato has never disappointed and I had some fantastic cheesecake there last night.  I don't feel a pressing need to find another place to get my gelato fix.

-1 star for service and cash only.
author: Chuck C.

description:
A-OK.

Came here to try their cannoli for the second time, hoping to like it more than the first time, but it didn't work.

Fill your cannoli upon order please!!
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Pastries overall: Good 
Coffee Products: Average
Cost: Too expensive for what it is.  $4.00 for a canolli? Seriously, maybe 3 bucks, 4?  This is my man complaint. Too expensive. 

Favorite pastry: Almond Croissant. This is GREAT. 

Funny thing about this thing is that there are a lot of people that work the counter and depending on who you get... your experience can go from mediocre-average-great. I just get my stuff and go.  I have no complaints about the service myself, but have heard others complain.
author: Amelia M.

description:
Maybe it's because we came after dinner, but most of the things we tried - madleines, cookies, amorettis, tasted a bit stale and hard.  The coconut macaroon, however was quite good - dense and chewy.

Prices are about par for an Italian pastry shop, which is to say not cheap.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
If you sell the same product as your competition down the street, you need to differentiate yourself on customer service. When you tell a customer something tastes like chocolate and it doesn't, you shouldn't charge them to buy something else instead. 

Pastries were okay...but nothing special
author: Kevin K.

description:
Not great service, but not bad. Seems to depend on the day. I don't go there for the service. 

I just go there for the BEST cannolis I've tasted in my life. Whenever I go to Northbeach, or even Chinatown I make a detour to hit it. Most cannolis I've tried on three continents have been crusty and dry: reason I've never been a real fan of cannolis. 

In contrast, these are moist and not sickeningly sweet. And my girlfriend who knows and who likes cannolis, along with her native born San Franciscan boss attest the quality of Mara's cannolis. In a paraphrase of a character created by a famous director and real estate investor in the area: "Leave the rest. Grab the cannoli."
author: Cork G.

description:
I love Mara's eclairs.  My mom has been taking us here for eclairs for years!
My mom comes to visit and asks for an eclair the minute we get into the city.

ummm... I can taste it now.....

A little pricey - for bucks a piece, but well worth it for a indulgence every once in a while!!
author: Olivera J.

description:
This is only my opinion and a humble, ignorant opinion at that. 

I got a double cappuccino and one of those custard clams (heh, I said "clam") to be eaten there.  It cost me $9.  

How did dessert/coffee/sweets cost more than my lunch?  Theoretically, I should be above judging stuff based on price.  But I'm broke.  And still hungry.

The clam thing was dry and so sweet.  So sweet.  Keep away from children.  

Cappuccino was darn tasty.

$9 is a lot of clams.  

Who am I to deny myself?  I'm an extraverted, intuitive, judgmental, thinker.  I judge.  Therefor I am.  And I judge this as just too expensive.
author: Christina C.

description:
After eating plates of carb-filled pasta dishes, you have to have room for dessert. :)
It's tradition for my out-of-town friends I to visit Mara's after our pasta-gorging.
It's so humble and small, and there is usually one or two people working.  Little intimate tables for your intimate conversations.  
Not the best tiramasu, but the chocolate eclaires and cannolis and bicottis are my favorites.  And they have so many pastries and baked goods, you are bound to find your top 3's. 
It's a lot, lot, waayyyy more afforadable than most cafes in North Beach.  
You can get a cannoli, a biscotti, and two cappaccinos for under ten bucks.  That's, like, one piece of dessert at one of your other pricey Italian places on Columbus. 
Andddddddddddd last time I went, they played two songs by The Smiths.
Mara's is way cool, dude.
author: Nahren K.

description:
I've been going through pastry withdrawals. I used to have fixings of cake and sweets on a weekly basis, but it's been a few weeks now.  I've always walked by their window drooling, so I finally gave it a try last night.  They have a large selection of cookies, pastries, bread, and just everything. It all looked really yum. I looked at the tiramisu and then to the cannoli and back and forth.  I decided not to be gluttonous and settled for one thing - cannoli wins!  I will say that the tiramisu and a few of the cakes looked a tad soggy, so I went for the cannoli.

The cannoli was good, but it wasn't mind-blowing. I guess I should've gone for the cakes.  I'm still a fan of Stella's, BUT I won't judge this place on ONE piece of pastry. Trust that I will give it a second try.  I won't judge the cakes by the way they look next time. I promise! :)
author: Dolores L.

description: Excellent selection, service is ok, food is fresh and authentic! The pastries we tried (some cannoli and a napoleon) were amazing! It reminded me of bakeries we visited in Europe. Highly recommended!
author: Christiaan V.

description:
Randomly walking by and stopped in here for dessert on a week night.

A few people inside but not overly crowded.  The woman working the counter was very nice.  I had 2 cannollis (1 there and 1 to go).  Not the best cannollis I've ever had and definitely not the worst.  The chocolate coating was a very nice touch.  My friend had the mint chocolate chip gelato.  She admitted it really wasn't gelato but she had a mint craving and wanted it (she's pregnant).

Total came to just under $11 for the three items.

Menu had tons of coffees on it and there were many other Italian pastries (and some not-so-Italian) to choose from.  Interior was clean.  No public restrooms.

If I'm in the area strolling by again I'd probably stop in again.  As we continued our walk we saw other Italian bake shops within a few bocks so we may try one of those too.
author: Debbie E.

description:
It sounds like the gentleman who works at this shop could use some lessons in customer service and affable social skills in general but he was not there when I visited so this review is based on their chocolate chip cookie, chocolate-dipped palmier, Florentine lace cookie, and raspberry ring.

Chocolate chip cookie: A tad bit too Chips Ahoy-ey in my opinion.  Too much dry dough, a little short on chocolate, and it didn't taste super fresh to me either.  Still, it might be worth writing home about...to tell your mom that her chocolate chip cookies are definitely better than the ones at Mara's. Anyways, I guess they don't claim to make tasty American cookies so on to the Italian goods...

Chocolate-dipped palmier: I was wrong - not everything tastes better when kissed with chocolate.  Maybe it was because we went so late at night, but the palmier tasted almost stale to me.  Flaky, yes, but not very flavorful...especially the portions dipped in chocolate.

Florentine lace cookie: I love these cookies!  Thank you to the nice lady working behind the counter for telling me their name.  Prior to last night I bumbled like an idiot describing those cookies to my friends as "kinda like Pepperidge Farm brussels cookies, but definitely no mint...and like not really as much cookie on the outside...super thin and extremely crunchy...ya know what i'm talking about?"  Anyways, I bought the cookie last night and ate it this morning with a big glass of lactose-free, calcium-enriched milk.  (Yeah, I know you're jealous.)

Raspberry ring: This pastry was the standout of the night!  Lots of raspberry woven into the flaky pastry and it was sticky with sweetness!  Much tastier than it looks.  Next time I see one of these puppies it will be hard to resist.

So...2 out of the 4 goodies were actually good...sounds like a 3 star performance to me.  Ciao!
author: Krystle S.

description:
We ordered two one-shot espressos.  The guy gave us two espresso cups each with only 30% filled with contents, about 15 ml.  This is noticeably less than the usual quantity of 25 to 30 ml (around 1 fluid ounce) as per Wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Espresso.  As we raised questions, he asked us if we had an espresso before (in an insulting manner), and then filled up the cups with hot water, telling us that's the way it should be.

To us, the guy obviously split one shot of espresso into two cups, and calling it as two.  He is right that we are not Italians, and that we did speak a foreign language other than Italian upon entering the store, but we are still customers that they should treat with honesty and respect.
author: William L.

description:
Second only to Stella (and even that's debatable) and just across the street!

Every dinner in North Beach should be followed by a trip to either Stella or Mara's.
author: Jason H.

description:
I always try to visit Mara's when I'm in North Beach -- they have the most authentic Italian pastries. I love their window display -- it's just beautiful! Everything I've tried here is good -- it's always hard to decide what to order. 

I would have given 5 stars but the last time I was in, the person behind the counter seemed annoyed to have to serve us. He seemed more in tune with his iPhone then selling pastries.
author: Joanne B.

description:
Did a drive by on this place yesterday afternoon on my way to Costco.  My friend Em mentions to me that her favorite Italian pastry shop was right up the street.  

I replied, "If there's parking in the front I'll stop, otherwise I'm going to continue driving..."

As luck would have it there was a spot.

We hop out of my car and waltz into the store.  I never used to waltz into stores in the past, I usually limbo'd or even did the Robocop, sometimes even threw in a little Cabbage Patch to spice things up.  But this afternoon I was feeling the vibe so I waltzed right in.

I ordered an Eclair, and Em ordered a Canoli.  Delicious.
author: Dennis M.

description:
I hate bad service.  This place sometimes has hideous bad service.  Usually I'd be ripping this place apart.  

But the pastries are THAT GOOD.  They're training a new batch of help, perhaps that will make it easier to bear.
author: Plot T.

description: WOW! Too many choices, decide quickly, you could change your mind all day. Bring cash.
author: E H.

description:
My love of dessert and adoration of NY's Little Italy brought me to Mara's (that and the huge window which displays all the pasteries!)

Inside is a small bakery whos window sill is filled with italian specialties such as rasberry wreaths and flat italian cinnamon bread, then of course there is the glass case of Napoleans, cookies, and gelato!

Sure, I probably should have tried one of their italian specialties (Napoleans are what they are known for) but I never follow any suggestions and instead we went with a lemon cookie, a cinnamon cookie, an apple turnover, and a bear claw (What can I say...I like dessert)

If you dont like super sweet stuff, my review is not for you. But if you were a sugar-aholic like me growing up... please continue...

The lemon sandwich cookie was tasty (very similar to shortbread with powered sugar and lemon filling) I didnt find this to be sweet enough for my taste though.

The cinnamon cookie was very tasty, much like a snickerdoodle, it was soft and just the perfect amount of sweet.

The bear claw was very big (enough for 2 days of snacking!) but I was not fond of the filling, it had raisons (a new take for me) and was no where near the sweet I was hoping for. I think of Svenhard's (individually packaged goodness) when I think of bear claws and I want super sweet.

Apple turnover, my boyfriend had this one and said that it was amazing, it too was huge and definitely lent itself for a 2 days of enjoyment.

Next time I go I will try what they are known for, who knows my review may go up....
author: Sara Ann S.

description:
Its late on a Sunday evening right before Christmas and I'm struck with a deep need for The Cookie of My People.   So I grab my honey and grab a City Car Share and we head towards North Beach. 

For some reason pinole nut cookies are available all year round in San Francisco.  I have no idea why.  I thought they were Christmas cookies.  Whatever, i want them for Christmas, I will have them for Christmas Eve.  

Miraculously we find a parking space in front of Mara's... 

I'm used to these cookies being $16 a pound.  If you haven't had a pinole nut cookie before they're excellent -- the main ingredient is butter and almond paste.  So the price doesn't bother me at first.  Actually, I don't bat an eye at it.   But I take the three stars away, dear Mara, because you get all your baked goods from Dianda's, and while they make a lovely cookie and a lovely cannoli -- the best of each in The City, I would dare to say -- they sell the cookies for $8 a pound at their Mission street location. 

An $8 a pound mark up?  Really.   

So, two stars for being open late on a Sunday night -- but really, what kind of Roman Catholics are you!?
author: Nora B.

description:
Walking by this place almost every day on my way to lunch has lured me in a few times. Unfortunately they only take cash, which is NEVER on me. So after passing by a few times and absolutely CRAVING a pastry by now I walk in finally with some cash and see a cream horn, something I've been craving for over a year. 

The display of pastries is a bit overwhelming, half of the pastries and pizza laid out in the street window and the rest in a case. After seeing everything I realize I can't just order one thing! So I get a cherry turnover as well. The man behind the counter asks if I would like this to go and I reply , yes. So he stuffs everything in a brown paper bag, as I eye the little pink boxes behind him. Why does he give me a little brown bag instead of a pink box? Hell if I know. I should deduct a star because of that. 

Extremely excited to devour my cream horn why I get home I bite into it and realize that this isn't made of real cream, like an eclair cream, which I'm used to. It has freakin whipped cream? Not even a good whipped cream, like store bought coolwhip or something. My cherry turnover was burnt and not fresh at all. I don't understand why I came here. 

Don't let the alluring display of everything they have to offer fool you. The pastries suck. I don't know why everyone is loving this place? And I have yet to fill my cream horn craving. Lesson Learned: Don't go to Mara's.
author: Sarah T.

description: My boyfriend and I walked by here a couple of weeks ago and stood drooling by the window for a while. Unfortunately we had our dog with us and no cash so didn't go in, but have been talking about it since. I had to go down that way today so decided to pull out cash give in to temptation. I have no idea what either if the things I got are called, but they were delicious!!!!! The first was this round pastry (kind of like a rope) with some kind of raspberry jam in it and sugar on top.
