It was really really good!! Really sweet but not so much that it was over the top. The pastry was flaky and had a great flavor to it. The second thing was recommended by the guy serving me. It was a diamond shaped pastry with two of the corners folded in to the middle, with an apricot (I think anyway) kind of jam in the middle of it. Again, this was delicious. Just the right amount of sweet and the jam was so tasty. The pastry was a puff pastry (which is my favorite) and it was just right. They were both a really good size too. I paid $7.50 which I thought was reasonable. I wish they took card as well as cash, but luckily there are plenty of ATMs around so it's not really a big deal. The guy that served me was really friendly also, which is always a good thing! Will definitely be going back soon!!!!!!
author: Elle B.

description: Yummy baked goods. Great coffee. I could do without the guy going back to filling the canolis after handling the cash though.
author: Cary C.

description: Nutella latte is a must! This place feels like a little slice of Italy. The pastries are amazing and the Nutella latte was so good that i ordered two. The owner greeted all of us with a smile and made you feel right at home. The next time I'm in San Francisco I'll go back for sure!!
author: Ryan R.

description: When people come into town, we always end up in Little Italy, and one of the places we stop at after a great meal is Mara's.  They have never let us down.  From the espresso and cookies, to the cafe cakes.  It really is a wonderful little treasure in this city of San Francisco.
author: James J.

description:
I found Mara's with a friend of mine while we were in North Beach one weekend.  That was over 5 years ago and I keep coming back.  The best pastries and selection.  I love the cannoli!

Everytime I'm there the line is always out the door.

This was a great find!
author: Gina O.

description:
Mara's seduces you with the window display and then you step inside and the glow is gone. The aging interior and dimly lit cases ruin the euphoric state I usually find myself in when I know that dessert is on the horizon. 

Not a romantic date spot and I wouldn't come out of my way to get here, but, if you need a quick place to pick up a little caffeine and a little sugar-rush, Mara's is always there for you. A well-made cappucino and a tasty chocolate dipped madeleine (I know, not Italian) made for a great way to start off a pub crawl.
author: Erin M.

description: DELICIOUS!! You can't window shop in this area without getting pulled into this place. The display sells itself and yes, it tastes just as amazing as it looks!!  The coffee could use a little more attention. It was really watery and kind of dampered the experience, but so long as they remain as focused as they are in their delicious desserts, then I will continue to drag the boyfriend here to indulge in their cannolies!!
author: Hamburger Yelper O.

description:
Raspberry wreath, bear claw, and almond croissant. Mc-AWESOME.

I don't mind the run-down look. It gives it a homey feeling. The people operating the place barely speak English which may add a little flair. The pastries did not disappoint. I don't care much about the service since it was just a pitstop, but so far so good.

The bearclaw is to die for. Looks like a croissant but smothered with almonds and glaze. HIghly recommended!

Didn't check anything else out in the area, but the display was too enticing to pass up. They taste as good as they look so come by for pastries !
author: Charles L.

description:
I love cannolis here, they are really light, not too sweet like in most places, and the filling is just melting in your mouth. Just try them, you won't be disappointed. 
I have never tried anything else here to be honest, except regular coffee, which wasn't so good, so 4 stars just for cannolis.
author: Ksenia B.

description:
The Italian wedding cookies here are awesome. I took my mom here to get a few since they taste like one of her favorite childhood cookies (sandtarts). 

As we were drooling over all the pastries and cookies, Mom (who is outrageous like Jem) whispered in my ear "those cookies dipped in chocolate look like a scrotum full of balls." Before I could even start laughing, my mom and I noticed the woman in front of us frown and cringe. "Oh no, did you hear me?!" she asked. As it turned out, the lady was making a face at something else, but then was super curious to know what was said. Mom indulged her and as we all started laughing, we all noticed that the cookie on the side of it looked JUST like a penis with some balls! They *had* to do that on purpose! What function could that shape possibly play for a cookie?! 

Though my mom was tempted by the penis cookie (as a lesbo, I was repelled), she ended up getting the pastry that looked like dentures. She rated it a 4/5. My regular-looking Italian wedding cookie was about that too.
author: Chrissy Q.

description:
Mmm.... almond cookie.... mmmmmmm.... raspberry cookie. Two cookies came out to $1.50 (it was weighed). I tried to stay away from items that looked overly sweet and was quite happy with the two cookies I walked away with today. The almond cookie was topped with handful of almonds. The raspberry had just a sprinkle of powdered sugar. Yum. 

If you don't have a sweet tooth, I highly recommend trying these two items. Place was a bit pricey, but it was worth a try.
author: Teresa Y.

description: Good Pastries... coffee is just self serve pot on a broiler though
author: Prescott f.

description:
This place is the opposite of a tourist trap, which can be hard to find in North Beach.  This bakery is as authentic as you can get, complete with adorable elderly Italian men reading La Gazzetta dello Sport.

Seeing the pastries from outside the window is enough to make anyone start salivating.  The classic tiramisu is fabulous, canelloni not overly sweet, custard clams rich, & the mille-feuille is delectable.

The counter clerk can be a bit gruff, but don't let that deter you from the best bakery in SF!
author: Jessica H.

description:
Mara's doesn't look like much, but they churn out delicious pastries. My favorite is the cream horn. The coffee isn't bad either. 

Be prepared, they only take cash!
author: Kelly C.

description: I had the most amazinggggg cannoli. Only problem I had was the small portion and high cost. I'd come back for the cannoli, but I'd probably go for the bigger portion and split it with someone.  But I will definitely be back to try their nutella latte.
author: Jen P.

description: We go here almost every time we're in the North Beach area! Been going here for years! Last time I had a Napoleon and a Cafe Latte, it was divine!! =)
author: Suki B.

description:
Many people tend to look past this paradise, as from the outside, it does not seem like there is much to look at. But they make a fantastic double espresso and pastries that just melt in your mouth.

Screw your diet! life is too short: have a cannoli.
author: Eloïse A.

description:
I've been here a couple times. I forget what I got the first time, and what the name of the 2nd thing was called, but then I got some chocolate ruggulah and it was so good!! ...so then I got some more :)

It's a cute little place with a few small tables. Can't wait until the next time I happen to be walking by. I will definitely be getting some ruggulah, mmm.
author: Caitlin B.

description: Reading one of the former reviews, I would have to say that the food is not necessarily the problem here, but the service folks that work there are really bad.  My experience involved the counter person picking up my pastries without washing her hands and handling money as well.  Yes, I did ask for a different pastry; but, she was not happy about.  Of course, all of this interaction happened while she was talking to a friend on the phone.  The pastries were okay, but great customer service actually enhances the experience of eating out--you tend to ignore mediocre fare.  My lesson is that I'll eat at Stella's or Volare in the neighborhood.  The folks appreciate their customers, the food is consistently fresh, AND they wash their hands.
author: Criss R.

description: Fun local Italian bake shop. The window displays are exquisite, but I wouldnt try them if they have been sitting there for too long. My friends and I ordered the cannolis and picked up some cookies to bring back to Marin. Great spot!
author: Brittany B.

description:
The only reason why I go to Mara's for well over a decade is their Napoleons.  Now I'm not sure if they make them (as another reviewer said they're made at another bakery in the MIssion), they are damn good.  Forget the cannolis (though I hear they're good) and eclairs...if you love custard and layers of flakey crust with what appears to be whipcream, sprinkled in shaved chocolate, THIS is for you.

Now why not 5 stars?  Well the place is well located, and their coffee has been recommended (though there is better coffee to be had elsewhere in North Beach according to my java snob friends), but there is a guy who works there who comes with a lot of Guido attitude...to the point that makes you wonder if he even bothers washing his hands after handling the money and then handling the desserts.  Just not sanitary practices...otherwise, you gotta try the Napoleons.
author: Kona L.

description: One of my fav spots in SF to get a desert and coffee after dinner in N. Beach or China Town. I shared a Tirimisu tonight and we scooped it up with a couple molasses cookies. Not great for my waist, but really good for my soul.
author: Adam X.

description: I tried the pizza bread here...and it was just okay. The rest of the pastries looked pretty good, so when I come back, I'll have to give those a try!
author: Dee N.

description: My daughter was born in North Beach and we all have fond memories of this little pastry shop on Columbus, with the sweets in the window. Upon her return from Italy, where she's been for many years, I thought it would be nice to return for a walk down memory lane. Upon entry, there was a long line, and we patiently waited. There were 2 ladies, only one working, the other one eating as the long line got even longer. The lady behind the counter touched the pastries with her hands before putting them in the box. The attitude was unhelpful as we were trying to decide what to order and the "worker" - if you can even call her that- with her mouth full, dirty hands (touching food and touching money) clicked her teeth, charged us $33.30 for a small box of stale cookies. Never again!!!! Mai piu! How can they call themselves masters of Italian pastries?? My city is ruined. Sad Sunday. Magari...
author: Drew G.

description: If you can get to North Beach and can afford the calories, you MUST come here for dessert.  Forget the lack of ambiance, you won't care where you are because as soon as you see the exquisite pastries filling the display cases, you'll think you've gone to heaven.  Once you've eaten one of the pastries, you'll know you're in heaven and you don't ever want to leave.  Kudos on a fantastic place!!
author: Judy B.

description:
If my review was based soley on the mango strawberry cheesecake, it would be 5 stars + 1 that doesn't exist.  However, the guy behind the counter is grouchy, ALL THE TIME!  and the place is reminiscent of a rundown donut shop, but oh man, the deserts make up for the rest!

I'm a cheesecake purist but was forced to eat my words with the amazing Mango Strawberry cheesecake atop a graham cracker and pound cake like crust.  I could hear music as I took my first bite!
author: J P.

description: The Florentines are amazing, the biscotti is great, and the coffee is good.
author: David H.

description: We discovered Mara's bakery while walking the streets of North Beach searching for that perfect gelato spot. It turned out to be Gelateria Naia, across the street. Anyway, the pastry display in the window of Mara's was impressive and we had to go in to see what it was all about. I am not a pastry fan, but still looked in the cases and then I looked down and saw all these flavors of biscotti and had to have some. My favorites were pistachio and the almond (plain, chocolate chip, and with white chocolate). Now, biscotti is hard and I don't drink coffee, but put it in the microwave for 10 seconds and it softens up and is delizioso. Other reviewers mentioned the not so friendly service and we encountered that from a man who looked Italian and didn't speak to us except to say the price. All in all, I'd go there again for biscotti next time I visit SF.
author: Tammy G.

description: I've been to Italy and these pastries are just as good. We were in town for 3 days and we were there 5 times. The raspberry pastry dipped in chocolate was outstanding, as well as everything else we tried. The proprietors really know how to make pastries. You can tell this is an art that has been passed down from generations and that they have a real passion and talent for food. This place is a must go! There is a nice seating area inside and out. It is casual, friendly, and reasonably priced.
author: Ellie T.

description: $9.50 for 1 eclair and 1 cannoli may be worth it fresh out of the oven melt in your mouth.. here they were tasty but pretty general and dried out.
author: Barbara C.

description: Previously I gave this shithole 5 stars based on the conoli alone. Today my wife and I had the tirsmasu and the shvogatella. Both crap.
author: Michael D.

description: Food is so so for the high price.  YOUR ATTITUDES need some realignment !!  Listen to your reviewers ?!   I did not want to give one star.
author: Jack O.

description:
I was in North Beach waiting for a friend on a rainy day so where do I head to? A bakery of course! 
Mara's display of pastries in the window totally tempted me to go in. They had SO many options - everything from morning pastries, to cookies, to desserts... it took awhile, but I finally settled on a cannoli, and a lemon pecan bar. 
First, maybe I'm ignorant - this is, after all, my first experience at a North Beach bakery - but I felt like this place was over priced. $2.50 for a cannoli that can easily be consumed in 2.5 bites?! 
The lemon pecan bar was $3.50, but HUGE. Definitely shareable between two people. 

The cannoli was pretty standard - although I don't have many other cannoli experiences to compare to, so its hard to say. The lemon pecan bar was delicious! Layers of pastry between (what tastes like) real lemon preserves and pecan bits. Very tasty, but also extremely sweet. I couldn't really handle more than 1/4 of it in one sitting (that's saying a lot because I eat a lot of sugar). 

Try this place out -- pretty good, and the desserts and pastries are ginormous! Minus one star for the price. I'd probably come back and try something else.
author: A. F.

description: So it was our wedding anniversary and my hubby took me on a day trip to San Francisco.One of our stops was this bakery . When I walked in I felt like I died and went to heaven so many pastries. Anywho I tried the chocolate dipped Cannoli being my first time ever trying one I thought it was delightful. The ricotta filling was sweet but not too sweet just perfect. The worker was super nice and he even gave me a free pump of germ-x lol
author: Viri A.

description: Discovered this bakery while we were walking around little Italy on our visit to San Fran. I was drawn in by the huge pastries that you can see right through their window. I tried their chocolate dipped cannolli's along with a chocolate "twisty" pastry that is outside near their window. All were wonderful treats and very satisfying!!
author: Foodie O.

description: I used to be a huge fan of this place and it still makes a fine cannoli but the pizza and coffee are mediocre. There other pastries are good but not great. Still pop in here when i end up in north beach
author: M. W.

description: Okay pastries.  Next time will probably try any of the multitude of other nearby shops.  Not very friendly or organized.  Got SO the $3.95 treat that she wanted, handed the dude a ten spot and he just disappeared on me.  I look around, like "whoa dude, where did he go?" and there was $1.05 sitting on the counter.  When dude returned, I was like, "yo slick, I gave you ten" and he gave me a nasty and disbelieving look, but looked in the register and there was a tenner in the fiver spot.  So he grabbed five and thrust it at me without so much as a sorry or thanks.  Okay, people, I'll say it again... customer service and attention to detail!  It's not rocket science, slicksters.  Probably would give a 3 based on serviceable pastries, but such rude service deserves only the lowest rating.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Everything looked delicious, but when there's a cannoli, that's what I'm gonna get.  Nice creamy but not-too-heavy filling with some dark chocolate chips tossed in here and there, and a crisp, buttery shell.  If they served dessert wine and had a few more tables, I'd give 'em another star.
author: Andi T.

description: Mom and I strolled into this little cafe after the most hilarious comedy routine I've seen so far by Paul Mooney at Cobb's. You'd think I'm a Cobb's whore, but really they've been booking great acts this year. Anyhoo, we stroll in late at night (stays open until Midnight on weekends) and ordered some lattes and feasted on some of the tastiest Italian pastries. The cannolli was delish, almost as great as the very first one I ever had out in Boston. Crispy shell, smooth ricotta filling with bits of chocolate. Swoon! The place is a feast for the eyes as the glass cabinets are filled with pastries galore. A nice ending for a fun-filled night.
author: Farah S.

description: Hands down: the best in North Beach for pastries.  The raspberry rings are incredible, as is the biscotti and canoli.  The old Italian guy is a true gent and God help me if I happen to stop in because I'll walk out with $20+ worth of sweets I know I shouldn't be eating if I ever want to fit into these pants I just bought!
author: Kevin W.

description: Delicious, moist chocolate cake and although the raspberry twist wasn't quite as good as the one I had while camping in Butano State Park, Mara's is still a nice place to pick up a pastry when you're in North Beach.
author: Nathalie L.

description: Had a chocolate cannoli today at Mara's and was very surprised at how good it tasted. I've previously been addicted to their tiramisu. The cannoli wasn't overly sweet but it had the perfect cheesy, creamy taste to it. I'll see how it compares when I go to Italy in a few weeks... but for now this bakery remains at the top of my list! As far as service, I mean it's an Italian bakery for goodness sakes, you don't expect big smiles and waiters, just take your food and be happy with it.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description: I used to avoid this place, being put off by the strange window display of pastries and pizzas laid out in the sun on flat trays on the window shelf, kind of dried out and over exposed.  But the more I've tried the pastries, the more I like it.  The canoli's are great and the ice cream wonderful (especially when they fill the small cups way over full, so it's like twice what you expected.)  I got a great chocolate dipped biscotti there once, and enjoyed the platter of mixed cookies I over-indulged in one night at a wine and boxing party.
author: Today Y.

description: For about $5 you can have any pastry in the house, and while that might seem like a pretty penny you have to keep in mind that these delicious deserts are as rich as a full meal and as liquored up and a long island ice tea. Open till 10:30 during the week and midnight on weekends means you can always stop by after seeing Larry Flint's strippers down the street.  Everything I've had was good, which includes just about everything, go for something with fruit, it's fresh.
author: Ian H.

description: This is a great little hole in the wall coffee shop with great italian pastries. True, most places in North Beach might meet this description, but this one is still rather tasty.  They make a killer cannoli, one of them is enough to make your heart ache, your arteries clog but your tastebuds sing for joy.
author: Herbert S.

description:
I stumbled upon Mara's about a week ago when I was tricked into walking from Fisherman's Warf to the Powell Bart. Famished, I looked into the golden window and spotted the most beautiful palmier I had ever seen.  After I had satisfied my tummy, my eyes began to feast on the other pastries, cookies, and coffee drinks the authentic patrons were enjoying--most of the people in the cafe were Italians, speaking Italian, ordering in Italian, being Italian with their espresso. So, a few days later, I brought my grandmother who was visiting from Georgia here to have a coffee and a palmier. The palmier is significant because they taste exactly like an old patisserie that used to be in St. Louis, MO--my grandmother and I used to dine there, "Andre's" every day that she visited when i lived there. They decided to close one day, and we haven't found what they called "butterflies" that tasted the same since. Mara's "butterflies" (palmiers) were JUST RIGHT. I can't find them made like this anywhere else--crunchy and sweet on the outside and doughey and moist when you pull them apart. My boyfriend attests that the cannoli is quite good and authentic, being less cream and more cheese.

I can't recommend a better hole-in-the-wall coffee & pastry shop.
author: Caroline C.

description: Great cookies and pastries. I really liked the pignoli nut cookies and the biscotti. You might want to get a bunch and share with some friends.
author: Dana L.

description: I was a bit embarassed that I was only introduced to this place from some people visiting from out-of-town but I was happy I found out. You really can't go wrong - everything is delicious! It's definitely worth it.
author: Jon N.

description: Worth taking their tiramisu for a spin. Also gelato in a handful of flavors that rotate in and out to keep me popping back in and out of Mara's
author: Brandon R.

description: Mara's is a mom and pops traditional Italian bakery located in the heart of the Northbeach District (SF's Little Italy).  With a bevy of tasty treats ranging from basic baked cookies to out of this world eclairs and cannolis stacked higher than Coit Tower, this is THE place to sin in sweets.  Don't worry, you can always take a walk around the neighborhood after indulging to get over your guilt.  It's a little bit pricey but super worth it, you're not gonna find stuff this authentic anywhere else.  Open late and later on weekends, I've been going here since I was a tot and a trip to SF is incomplete without a traditional Italian custard filled chocolate eclair.  The custard, oh my god, it's decadent but simple and good gooey.  Makes you feel like you're in Grandma's kitchen in Calabria and she's gonna smack you for ruining your appetite before dinner.  Forgettaboutit!
author: Ella L.

description: I'll have to check this place out more. It's not terrible, but for now, al I can say is that Mara Italian Pastries doesn't even compare to Stella Pastry. The presentation alone makes Mara seem like it came from a third-world country. When it comes to aesthetics, portion, price and taste, Stella wins.
author: Jonas T.

description:
So first on the service..I personally love both the guys the work the morning shifts. To the point crazy Italians. Sure they have nice tough shells, but try being nice to them, worked for me!

Now the coffee.. In my mind Lavazza espresso is tough to beat, and that's what brews at Mara's. Always get a white dbl mocha and its always delicious. 

Pastries... Cannolis are a must, same goes for the Napoleons. Tiramisu is pretty good, but not the best. the coffee cake has a fantastic crumb topping! OMG and the classic anise biscotti always crisp and fresh mmm...everything is damn good, just a matter of taste, go try for yourself, if you can find parking.
author: jessica b.

description: Craving cannolis near midnight on a weekend?  So was I.  Look no further.
author: Rego S.

description: Rude uncaring employees that don't speak English well. Food products use low quality ingredients and preservatives.
author: Anthony P.

description: Overpriced and no hygiene.  Went in because my girlfriend wanted a quick dessert.  First off, nothing there looks fresh and all the chocolate covered pastries were sweating.  Nonetheless, we got a medium sized pastry and a small cannoli (small as in 1.5 inches) which totaled $6.45!  Also, the Mexican/Italian lady with the over-sized nails behind the counter picked up my cannoli with her bare fingers!!  SO GROSS!  Tourist keep this place running.  I wish they knew better so it would go out of business and an authentic Italian pastry shop can open up.
author: Jason L.

description:
mmmmmmm  mm! 
napoleon cake=wowowowowow!
chocolate eclairs=so-so.
apple turnovers=yum!
cherry strudel things=where are my stretchy pants?
guy working the counter=could be friendlier, but cute. eh.
will probably be going back.
author: Melisa B.

description:
the pastries lined in the front window invite you to come in and introduce yourself. and if you don't see your type in the front window, then you're sure to find them in one of the two display cases inside.

the prices are a little steep but a bite into either the plain or chocolate cannoli will take your mind of it. or a sip of their espresso can warm you up on a overcast day. their eclairs, muffins and assorted cakes could hit the right spot as well.
author: Lola L.

description: Came here to get a slice of tiramisu but it was toooo sweet. It was good but too much sugar for my taste. It's not cheap too. $5.00 for a slice. If you think it's worth it and you're a sweet tooth type of person then come on right in.
author: Tracy A.

description: It's not great it's not bad.  One day I had a sweet tooth and walked out of here with a bag full of goodies.  I think some of them were overpriced but then again everything is overpriced in SF.  I didn't see Mara but the man who helped me was pretty nice.  One bad thing was that after eating one of the cream filled pastry I felt sick but I got over it.
author: Dee Y.

description: Not great. Granted, I only tried a Cannoli - But they tossed the two I bought in a brown paper bag! .... What ever happened to the little pink pastry boxes that a well respected bakery ties up w/ a string? ... That's authentic! ... That's when you're in North Beach for dinner and want to hit up a cafe or bakery for desert not only have some there, but take some home with you for the rest of the week too. Like at Ferrara's in New York City - Now that's a f--king Bakery!
author: Tom P.

description: I'd pass on the biscotti. The cookies are good. The best is the chocolate chip cannoli is outstanding! It isn't too sweet. The chocolate isnt overwhelming. The filling is very creamy and addictive.
author: Ahna P.

description: If you aren't enticed simply looking at the goods in the window then you must be dead.  Flaky, buttery fruit turnovers and delectable italian cookies.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
4.5stars...

THANK U NICOLE FOR SHOWING ME THE WAY TO MARA's - can't believe I've been in this city my whole life and never knew about this gem! I have a couple of favorite spots in North Beach (Mario's is one of them) where I seem to end up every time I'm in the neighborhood ~ I have just added Mara's to the list. 

One Sat. night, my friend suggested we go to North Beach for pastries and coffee/mochas for a change instead of hittin' the clubs and gettin' drunk. I was totally down with this plan...so we walk into Mara's and I'm thinkin' to myself, this place is un-real, so many delicious lookin' options, how do I choose??? I've got a sweet~tooth people...and this could be dangerous. But I tried the choc. covered biscotti (thinking I should be good) while Nicole got the glazed cream puffs for us to share and a raspberry twist...YUM. 
We went down the street for our coffee, so we could sit at an outside table, people watch and enjoy our treats! We officially decided that on our death-bed, we'd be asking for cream puffs and raspberry twists and that someone had better know what we are talking about so they can run to Mara's to fulfill our dying wish....now with this all said, you may wonder why only 4.5 stars ~ after only 2 or 3 visits so far, I'd like to have a few more before I say "it's the absolute best" but I have no doubt it will be!
author: Mariel C.

description: You need to stop and get yourself some butter cookies to go.  I don't know about the other pastries - I just stick to the non-perishable biscotti and they are divine.
author: Bridget T.

description: Been going here for years now and I always get the napolean. By far it is the best I have ever had, and I get that damn pastry at just about every bakery I go to. Try the nutella coffee too.
author: nick a.

description: Delicious !  Great place for dessert after dinner or an assortment of little cookies !
author: Lynnesa E.

description: I have been to this bakery 2Xs in this summer.   Yes, the pastry is good, but the prices are out of control....Way too pricey for what you get.
author: michelle g.

description:
as a couple of my girlfriends and i walked back to our car from dining in north beach...we noticed the window display filled with goodies at mara's.

we were thinking of just taking a 'look' inside...but couldn't resist...so we each decided on ordering 1 pastry each and splitting them: 

-Tiramisu- eh...i would have to say that i've had better...
-Cannoli-  honestly...i can't remember too much about this one...
-Cream Puffs-  Yummy!  this is probably the only thing you should care to order here!   

next time...no more sampling for me...i'll just come back for the cream puffs!
author: Nancy T.

description: My friend and I stopped in last night  on a whim for two pastries after hearing great things about this place. I'd always passed by and like many others, I'm sure, been enticed by the window display. As "mom and pop" as I've read this place is, and as kind as they may be, all was overshadowed for me by the pricetag:  NINE DOLLARS!
author: Ash E.

description:
I have found the key to happiness in life. I will share it with you.

It is to carry a little dessert or some foccacia bread in your purse while you carry about your business during the day. Everytime you open your purse you get hit by a whiff of tasty, happy, buttery delights or take a peek at a little "gettin' greasier by the minute" brown bag. 

Now tell me doesn't that sound like heaven? 

I'd been to Mara's before. Who HASN'T been drawn in by the heavy scent of baked goods or a fogged up window filled with carb cloggin' delights (if I see a fogged up window I am happy because I know it's extra fresh; and that's a good thing non)? I'd more than sampled the baked goodies from the desserts they offer. Canolli? Hit or miss but when it's a hit, it's a m#therfarkin' hit! It'll hit your tasebuds with an assault comparable to the Mafia. Almond cookies, chocolate dipped, the little fruity ones--yummy! Gelato? So worth the price (because they give you a lot of it) and their coffee (lattes, capuccinos and all else) are equally worth your sipping pleasure (so much different than the "please don't burn all the taste buds off my tongue" variety we are all trying to hastily chug before going to work).

I always get waited on by the little old woman in the shop. She might not work a register well but she always gives me a sweet smile. I think she thinks I'm Italian. She once asked me something in Italian and I responded in REALLY BAD Italian (try Spanish made to sound Italian). She actually gave me an extra almond cookie for my butchered Italian on purpose! Cool! If it means I get slighty better service for this case of "mistaken identity", I'm all for it. 

But I'd never tried their foccacia until this weekend. I saw the tell tale fogged up window and a guy hastily pulling a tray away. Hmm...I thought...I NEED to try to that. So I made a haste right turn into the shop and bought myself a piece. Oh no, I didn't eat it right away. I had to SAVOR the smell. I walked (with John H. in tow--look I mentioned you by name for once!) from North Beach through Union Square all the way to the deYoung museum in the park. We smoked a little in the park (feeling the love of the Haight no?) and went back through the Haight, stopping at various stores along the way. Every single time I opened my purse (to find my wallet, my lighter, my cell phone b'cause I was one popular lady Saturday with all the texts) I was confronted with warmth and garlic and tomato sauce and green onions and butter in my nose! It was like having all the best parts of an Italian restaurant in my purse(ok not all the best parts--I don't have any hot Italian waiters hopping about in my purse). Finally as the munchies set in (around Divi and Haight) I plucked that little bit o' heaven from the blackhole that is my purse and me and the poor, ragged, "why did I agree to this psycho walk?", John H. and I DEVOURED this piece of foccacia in less than a minute. 

The experience was as satisfying as an orgasm and can be done on a city street. Plus it's legal and I don't have to worry about offending children and families (nice to know even the Haight has standards).

Seriously, buy a cookie, buy some foccacia, buy a canolli, buy a coffee, buy some gelato. They open at 7am and close no earlier than 10:30 at night. These treats will perk up your day and your taste buds. 
Think about a canolli or some foccacia at lunch, a latte first thing in the am the office or a cup of gelato after work. Mmmm.....

C'mon you know you want to....and you know the craving won't leave until you fill it. Trust.
author: Veronica G.

description: I don't like to give a business a bad rating, but I have to be honest. I ordered a chocolate cake that looked real yummy. But when I put my fork into it, it was as hard as a baseball, and it tasted like one too. I generally will eat anything that is chocolate, but I could not eat this "cake." The only reason they get two stars and not one is because I told her the cake was really dry and seemed old, so she let me choose something else. I got the cannoli.  But again, I was not impressed, as it did not taste fresh. But it was better than the baseball cake - so I ate it. Sorry Mara's, but I think you have some work to do.
author: Jo M.

description: I work at the Pasta P right around the corner here... so I stop in frequently for a little breakfast pastry before opening.... or sometimes for a tasty dessert (reward for putting up with people) on my way home... I've tried a few different things, and they've been good... not GREAT... but good. The employees are very sweet... I haven't tried the espresso, but the spumoni was delicious, and the employees are very nice to me when I try to speak my (VERY) broken Italian.
author: Elle Q.

description: If you want to get ripped off, this is the place for you!!!  We stopped in for tea, coffee and gelato before heading over to a show we were seeing.  Seemed easy enough...I ordered from a gentleman, probably the owner; me handed me my tea and gelato, my husband proceeded to get his coffee.  Thinking I was in a pay as you go place, it stood at the registered, informed the girl as to what I had ordered, she appeared to ring me up.  I handed her a $20, she gave me change, I put a dollar in the tip jar, and went to sit down with my party.  About 45 minutes to an hour later, we started to depart; I was accused of not paying my bill by, I think the owner.  I told him I paid the young lady, who suddenly went stupid and said she didn't remember my paying her, maybe it was someone else.  Seriously, there were only three people working, I think I knew which one I handed my $20 to.  The owner kept yelling that I should have paid him; and if I did in fact pay her, then prove it to him and show him the entry on the register.  And since they don't give receipts, it was my word against hers......  I have never been treated like this in my life!  The young lady just kept looking away saying she didn't remember me paying her, just couldn't remember.  I ended up just tossing another $10 at them, and vowed to write a review on every site I can possibly do so.   Yelp, done!  Trip Advisor, done!  Facebook here I come.
author: Jill C.

description: great pastries, coffee not bad too, no bathroom, very small place
author: Anonymouse Y.

description: Thanks to my Italian in-laws and Chicago upbringing I have a soft spot for old school Italian bakeries, and cannolis in particular. Mara's did not dissapoint on the cannoli front, and the delicious latte and old world atmosphere helped as well. I thought the service was fine, sure they're a little curt, but they were fast with the beverages and the Sunday afternoon when I visited was quite busy. I also liked that they had soccer on the tv. Sugary perfection.
author: Alison M.

description: I realize that Stella's Bakery is the best known Italian bakery in North Beach, but for my money (and taste buds) check out Mara's Bakery @ 503 Columbus Ave.  Not only are the pastries better, but the selection is triple that of Stella's!  It's a must stop for us whenever we're in the area. Anyone who enjoys pasteries will love it!
author: Kenny P.

description: I passed by this place a couple of times. But I didn't stop in until I got rid of all my friends. The napoleon was outstanding. Fresh and crisp, just right. The tiramisu was very good also. Just a bit heavy on the coffee taste but still good. Now I also had a cookie with the fudge drop in the center. I love those things and I can never pass them up. I should have. It was as hard as the rock I came back from. With all the humidity and being surrounded by an ocean, How can a cookie get that hard? Was I accidentally served the plastic display. It wasn't faded at all. What happened? I do forgive but never forget. I would go back here in a minute for the pastries, and they are open til midnight on Fri & Sat. . The gelato looked great but my plate was full. This is a must stop. That stupid cookie knocked off a star. Sorry.
author: Steven M.

description: Came here after lunch at Caffe Greco to get a small dessert. I had the chocolate covered madeleine (mediocre) and chocolate covered coconut  macaroon (pretty good). They have a variety of little pastries, including cookies shaped like baseballs, ice cream cones (I thought those were so cute) and dinosaurs. I think if I stop by another time I'll get the cannoli, I heard those were pretty good... that madeleine was disappointing.
author: S. D.

description: Oh man, this place is packed with yummy-looking stuff. I could have spent many dollars and consumed many calories here. The name says it all: this place has lots of Italian pastries and breads. All I can speak for, though, is the cannoli, which we took home with us for a post-dinner dessert. Yum!
author: Cheryl H.

description: In this day and age, who DOESN'T take credit cards? God, that is so annoying. I hate carrying cash! After I had picked out a nice little selection of cookies and had them wrapped up in a pink box and weighed, I had to run to the ATM to withdraw 20 bucks so I could actually leave with them. Besides that little blip in the road, the cookies were excellent. I took them down to washington square park and sat in the sun and ate them all. My favorite was the almond pignoli cookie--now, I'm not Italian, but my best friend is, and I'm sure she would put a stamp of approval and authenticy on these (if she lived here...sob). Perfectly chewy with nicely toasted pine nuts on top. The macaroon came in second best, and I forget the rest, but I know they were good. So, if you are ever wandering around North Beach, make a stop in here, but remember your dollars!
author: Jenna W.

description: They have cannoli, they have cannoli, and they are pretty good. So, that is the only thing I care about! I was craving for cannoli and I saw this place looks like an old style bakery with variety of Italian sweets and pastries. Friendly staff, too.
author: Daisy S.

description: Drool inspiring window display of fabulous pastries. We tried three of them and it was hit or miss. The Tiramisu was pretty good but a little heavy handed on the alcohol(depend on how you like yours though) The cannolis are really good...light, flaky crust with creamy chocolaty/pistachio filling. The Napoli was pretty bleh though...it was a bit too marcapone and pastry heavy...with fresh fruit it would have been much better..a little heavy otherwise. Overall, nice place...nothing to write home about though.
author: Nav T.

description: Can't vouch for anything except for the powdered sugar almond cookies.  They rock & are the perfect size to whet a sweet tooth.
author: Jenny M.

description: Canoli....Yummerz....The best italian canoli in the city I think. Everything else there I didn't care for much...! Don't waste that custard, lick the plate dammit..! Enjoy
author: Sven S.

description:
this used to be my favorite spot to get a cappuccino in north beach.   
now that i'm pregnant, this is my favorite spot to get a decaf cappuccino, a scone, a cookie, an apple strudel, a croissant, and pizza bread. 

i love the people that work here.  love to hear people gasp at the display window.  love the 2 tables outside.  love to hear about the owner's grandsons: Valentino and Vincente.  love Mara's.  the end.
author: Kelsey C.

description: I love Mara's Pastries.  Every time I go into the city,  I have to get me a couple of their raspberry twists.  It's so good.  Make sure you bring cash though because it's cash only.
author: MIchelle L.

description: They say North Beach is a relatively safe neighborhood, but I beg to differ--I live in constant fear that my insanely close proximity to Mara's will result in a lighter wallet and a heavier me.  So far I've been lucky, though limiting myself to one visit per week has been no easy feat.  Their Italian wedding cookies are INCREDIBLE and while I usually avoid anything doused in powdered sugar, I make an exception for these.  I'm not much of a breakfast person but there's something about sitting at the corner table, dunking a chocolate-dipped biscotti into their delicious coffee, and staring out into the street on a Saturday morning... =)
author: Lisanne A.

description: I was initially drawn to this place because of the variety sweet treats displayed through the front window. It was hard to decide what to get. It all looked so good. I like the freshly made biscotti - the white chocolate one with almonds. The e-clairs, gelato, and chocolate cake looked enticing. I will be back for more tasty treats when I'm in the neighborhood. There are chairs and tables inside but I usually grab sweets to go and not really sit.
author: Candace F.

description: Great pastries.  I like the eclairs with custard in the middle.  But the service is appalling.  Someone gave me a latte when I asked for a mocha.  When I took my latte to the counter and politely told one of the staff that I got the wrong drink, she began beating her chest and proclaimed, "I MADE THAT!"  She looked like she was going to beat me up.
author: Kandi K.

description: I have been here a few times with local friends and out of town guests and we always leave satisfied. Cannoli ( I go for the chocolate dipped) is great, and you can't go wrong with the tiramisu. Coffee is okay, but I'm here for the pastry !
author: Caroline O.

description:
I go to this pastry shop once in a while & I'd have to say their selection is just so-so.  It works in a pinch when other places are closed, but my last visit was a little disappointing.

I shared the following w/friends & found them all a little dry or blase.
- chocolate cake
- cheesecake
- tiramisu

I love dessert so I am an expert in this category!
author: D L.

description:
Never been disappointed here.

Cannoli and coffee and tiny tables and people-watching. Makes me all warm and fuzzy.
author: Nicole A.

description: We've gone here five times, and every time the service has been extremely unfriendly and curt. It may be the same guy who helps us every time, or at least he has the same bad tude. . Anyway, we're always happy to stroll in and order a box or two of pastries because they really are quite good, but by the time we leave I remember why it's months before we return. Today was our last visit. I give up! The food may be good, but it loses some of its good taste because of the guy(s) at the counter. We're sticking with Stella's from now on -- or Danllo's, which doesn't have the super gorgeous baked goods, but the friendly service makes their food a treat.
author: Maria G.

description: This place is the real deal. Heavenly gelato, amazing cookies, beautiful pastries. Friendly Italian man behind the counter. Felt like I had wandered into Italy! Can't wait to go back.
author: MK D.

description: Danger lurks in these shelves. Where no man dare go who... OK OK This place is where it's AT! Canolis, danish, eclairs, cookies and many, many other fresh confections lie in the displays. This place is a dieter's nightmare! Lucky for me, I've waved off diets for life. Hooray!
author: n b.

description: Yeah the service sucks, but the custard rocks.  Kinda pricey but what isn't these days.
author: The I.

description: Some really great drinks to be had here. My friend enjoyed his iced mocha with a really rich looking chocolate-dipped biscotti. I had this really incredible sounding AND tasting drink: a Nutella(tm) latte! Who would ever think this was possible? Wow, so glad I ordered it! And more hazelnut-y than overpoweringly sweet, which was a nice surprise. I also had a yummy square of pizza, a very simple slice that seemed to be similar to a pizza margherita, only with fresh green onion added. The only downsides to the experience was cash only, the somewhat gruff service given by the help, and his forgetting of my pizza he had set to warm up. Random aside: open air tour vehicles driving by with tour guides pointing to Mara's like we were part of the window display instead of patrons sitting outside, so we sorta pretended to speak in Italian, then also mix it up with some Tagalog. Yes, random indeed. Back to the center of things--I think I'll probably visit again for all the cool treats and coffee. Boy, thinking of Mara's, now I have a hankering for a good connoli--anyone game?
author: Ryan T.

description: After eating at Stella's I felt the cannoli was pretty good. My complaint therein lies in the price, BUT Mara's takes the gold! You get a true handmade cannoli in a decent size, done right, and for the right price. Whenever I see cannoli's I always eat with caution as no one makes them better than my nana did. The second I bit into the regular cannolo I felt like I was instantly brought back to my childhood. In addition, I ordered the focaccia pizza and fell in love instantly. The owner there told me he makes them fresh every morning along with all the other pastries there. Usually, I am like Anton Ego in Ratatouille when it comes to cannoli's and I had the same moment with the cannolo that Anton had with the ratatouille. Mara's is SUPERB! If you get a moment on Columbus Street I suggest you stroll into this little mom and pop and grab yourself a real piece of Sicily!
author: RaeAnne P.

description: I love this place. Even though I am a health nut, I always manage to snag a delicious cannoli from this place. They are amazing. The calories are well worth it :p
author: LJ S.

description: its too tempting! you can't pass this place after you've had a great dinner and now its time for some sweetness.  i had an eclair and my friend had the tiramisu. his was better, we had to switch! but the coffee taste in their tiramisu is very very strong. eclair was just okay. there's a wide variety of pastries to pick from. I say next time.. I'll get one of each, for review sake, ofcourse ;)
author: Food L.

description: Ugh. Awful pastries. Even day old doughnuts at safeway are better! Even my kids did not like the pastries ( 6 and 8)
author: norbert m.

description: The service here is really poor.  We went there and ordered an iced coffee, which we did not like and asked if we could exchange it.  They refused, and insisted that "this is how we make iced coffees."  The guy was very rude and unfriendly, why not choose another almost identical shop which has hopefully better service?
author: David H.

description: Great pastries! Tons of choices, very good. Pizza in the window should probably be avoided - may be good, but just looks a little off. Try the cookies and cakes!
author: Sara H.

description: Disappointed with the long line and general disorganized atmosphere of the ultra-modern gelato place across the street (or maybe it was the half-dozen or so idiotic, indecisive 14-year old girls), we ended up at Mara's for some chocolate gelato.  However, the cookie selection proved too tempting, and I went for an amazing pine-nut covered, almondy, chewy delight--one of the best cookies I've ever had!  The espresso was perfect too, with a nice, foamy crema.  The older couple running the place (the owners I assume) were very sweet and patient with the chaotic mess of tourists wandering in--a real talent in itself.  Very charming, unpretentious, and old-school mom-and pop kind of place--oh and the gelato was just as good as Naia's!
author: colette m.

description: well, i can't say much about the pastries (i can actually: that cannoli could've been a whole lot betta), but i do like their coffee here. it's pricey, but they use really good espresso, and those ladies could really whip it up in there. it's a cute shop with a delicious treats screaming from that window. and they were playing morrissey (live!), and well, i'm all over that.
author: Ru G.

description: the BEST cannolis on the planet. the only thing that blows about this place is they don't take credit or debit cards.
author: marcie d.
